title: BrewDog eyes up Inverness site for bar
story: A CITY bakery looks set to make way for a hip new bar in Inverness city centre.The Ashers bakery chain has confirmed this week that it is "at an advanced stage of negotiations" over vacating its premises in Church Street to make way for Aberdeenshire-based BrewDog.It was revealed last month that the pub chain, which has grown rapidly in the past few years and now employs more than  staff in dozens of bars across the UK, was keen to come to the Highland capital.While there has been no official confirmation from BrewDog itself Ali Asher, joint managing director of the Ashers chain, confirmed talks are progressing."Its clearly a very good site for that type of operation now," he said, adding that Ashers itself will not be leaving the city centre but simply moving."We have also identied a location round the corner on Union Street which we plan to relocate to at the same time," he said."We hope the necessary consents and assistance from the authorities and our local tradesmen will facilitate this being a smooth transition."Mr Asher also revealed plans for a refurbishment of his chains cafe at the Farraline Park bus station."We look forward to welcoming many loyal and new customers to both these shops and wish BrewDog all the best," he added.BrewDog was launched in Fraserburgh in  by friends Martin Dickie and James Watt, both then , with a mission to increase interest in craft beer.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Date set for Highland air traffic controllers strike
story: Air traffic controllers working for Highlands and Islands Airport Limitedare set to strike on April , affecting operations at Inverness Airport as well as in Dundee, Wick, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway and Benbecula.Members of the Prospect union will also take action short of a strike between April and August , in a continuing disagreement over their pay offer for -.This will include instruction to work to rosters an overtime ban and withdrawal of goodwill though Prospect says it will seek to agree a protocol with Hial to ensure cover for emergency incidents.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoProspect members have agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish school holidays have concluded."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays.ldquoI urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Eastgate road closed as hostel demolition work begins
story: Motorists are being advised that Eastgate inInverness will be closed at its junction with Crown Road to its junction with Inglis Street from today until Friday.The closure is to allow demolition work to be carried out at the former Eastgate Hostel building which starts this week, more than five years after the fire that left it gutted.Pedestrian access remains open and access for emergency services and delivery vehicles will be at the discretion of the works contractor.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Keep Safe scheme signs up new Highland sites
story: FRIGHTENED people seeking refuge now have more safe zones in which to get support in Nairn.Police Scotland and the I Am Me charity have welcomed new members to the arearsquos Keep Safe network, which gives people a place to gothey feel frightened, distressed or have been the victim of crime.Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau has joined the initiative, which is delivered in partnership between I Am Me and Police Scotland.The Keep Safe project aims to help people with a disability, feel safe within their community.I Am Me is a community partnership charity developed in Renfrewshire, to raise awareness of Disability Hate Crime.Gill Maclean, manager of Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been approved as a Keep Safe space and are keen to do all we can help vulnerable people feel safer and, therefore, more likely to venture out into the town.Inspector Judy Hill told the Courier: ldquoThis initiative aims to help vulnerable members of our communities, including the elderly and the disabled, to feel safe and know where to go for help and assistance should they require it.ldquoAll Keep Safe places are approved by Police Scotland.ldquoSometimes due to disability or age-related illness, people can easily become disorientated, lost or become confused, especially in and around unfamiliar surroundings.ldquoKeep Safe can offer a reassurance that there is somewhere people can seek assistancerequired.For more details about the scheme, go online at www.iammescotland keep-safe about-keep-safe Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Loch Ness Monster the subject of new master pie ce
story: To celebrate British Pie Week, pastry specialists Jus-Rol decided to create an art pie-ce of Nessie out of pies.The image is made up of more than  handmade pies, using a combination of shortcrust, puff and filo pastry.The masterpiece took three days to create and cocoa powder, currants, sesame seeds, caster sugar and brown sugar were used for the outlining and some of the detailing.Holly Bouldin from Jus-Rol says, ldquoJus-Rol, British Pie Week aims to inspire the nation to celebrate one of the greatest British classic foods and we wanted to pay tribute to that love by creating an impressive image which is synonymous with Scotland.As well as the artwork, Jus-Rol ran a UK-wide poll ahead of pie week, which runs next week. It uncovered that the average Scot eats three pies a month and Scotlandrsquos all-time favourite flavour was beef and ale.The poll also showed that one in  Scots bake a homemade pie twice a month. Andthere isnrsquot a rolling pin to hand Scottish people are the most likely, in the UK, to reach for a wine bottle as an alternative.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: Shock at extent of tree felling by the Caledonian Canal in Inverness
story: Councillor Duncan Macpherson believes too many trees have been chopped down to make way for the latest phase of the Inverness West Link.Oak trees have been brought down along the canal side to make way for a second swing bridge and poplar trees along the edge of the A at Glenurquhart Road have also been felled in the name of health and safety.Cllr Macpherson said he and many others were shocked to see the extent of the felling.He said: ldquoI can understand the need to have one or two trees down for the new swing bridge but it seems to me like theyrsquove just gone and taken every single tree down. Did they really need to do that ldquoI wouldnrsquot exactly call myself a tree-hugger but Irsquom thinking lsquoguys come on, are you sure you needed to take that many down rsquoInverness musician Roderick Mackenzie, who lives nearby and is concerned about protecting the environment, said it made him feel ill to see mature trees being cut down.ldquoThis is abuse of the environment, he said. ldquoItrsquos sickening.A council spokesman said it was ldquoalways troubling to see mature trees removed but insisted the scale of the operation was necessary.And he said an environmental survey had been carried out before the felling started to rule out the presence of bird nests, bat roosts and similar habitats in the trees.He added: ldquoThe poplar trees adjacent to the A were in very poor condition and would have needed signicant reductions or complete removal, regardless of the development.ldquoPart of the stage two works will develop park land and there is a comprehensive replanting plan incorporated into the works commencing later this year.Tuesday  Mar  : PM

title: art pranksters from banksys oscar nominated film to take part in aberdeens nuart festival
story: A collective of “art pranksters” who featured in an Oscar-nominated film by Banksy is coming to Aberdeen.Internationally acclaimed The Dotmasters will take part in Nuart Aberdeen, the popular street art festival that s to the city next month.As revealed in later editions of yesterday’s Evening Express, Anders Gjennestad, aka Strøk, and Hama Woods will also take part in the event.The Dotmasters’ work has been seen in Tokyo, Norway and London, and examines populist media with a typical British sense of humour. The work has also featured in both Banksy’s Cans Festival as well as his award-winning documentary Exit Through The Gt Shop.Nuart’s curator said the three artists’ use of stencil make them a valuable addition to the  line-up. Martyn Reed, who is also Nuart director, said: “It was seeing an early stencil of Banksy’s Laugh Now, a counterpoint to the regulated distribution of images, adverts and signs in public space, that triggered Nuart’s initial sht to Street Art in . A lelong obsession followed and these three artists have become an intrinsic part of that history.”Last month it was announced that Jan Vormann is bringing his Dispatchwork project, which uses LEGO bricks to repair damaged walls and structures, to the festival, which runs from April  to .

title: inspectors praise staff at aberdeen nursery05
story: Snack time at an Aberdeen nursery is relaxed and sociable, inspectors said.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited Summers Nursery on Victoria Street, Aberdeen, on January  and have now published their report.The nursery can look after up to  children at any one time and inspectors rated it “very good” for care, support and environment – the second best of six possible ratings.“Children’s health and wellbeing was promoted during snack and meal times,” the report said.It added: “We observed these times to be relaxed, sociable experiences, with the pace dictated by each child’s inidual needs.“Staff joined in with children’s conversations, supporting the development of children’s social skills and language development.“They praised and encouraged the children, which helped them to feel safe, protected and included.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

The following morning, the girl’s parents filed a missing persons report with the police.   Officers traced the girl within Davidson’s bedroom who was getting dressed. Davidson could not explain why he didn’t phone the police when the girl went to his house the previous night – knowing she was only . His mobile phone was seized and police interviews were carried out. During an interview with the teen, officers asked what she made of her being  and Davidson being . She replied that he told her “It was only  years and didn’t matter.” A number of text messages found on his phone discussed how the pair planned to have sex together. A message sent from the girl said: “It’s my first time and I don’t know what to expect.” Davidson replied: “There’s nothing to worry about gorgeous.” And he also messaged how he “could never get enough” of the teen. Solicitor Steven Maxwell said: “He’s hidden this matter from his father.   “The narration was given to my client’s father to understand the prediciment his son is in.” Sherf Scott Pattison said he would defer sentencing for the preparation of reports. The Sherf told Davidson: “You’ll be interviewed by a social worker and you need to give them the information they ask of you. “Because of the nature of these offences you’ll be subject to the Sex Offenders’ Register from today. “When you’re sentenced you’ll be told theof time for. The Sherf further warned: “And given the nature of the charges – although I’m not ruling out custody, you should prepare yourself for custody.” Davidson admitted engaging in sexual activity with a -year-old and sending her messages of a sexual nature.

The Royal National Leboat InstitutionAyr branch announced their closure after it struggled to keep afloat. The branch, which has been around for over  years, issued an urgent appeal last November, appealing for a younger generation to pitch in to save the Ayr branch . Committee member and Secretary Robin White, said: “Sadly the number of volunteers helping to run the branch recently has been dwindling, to such an extent that so few are left the AGM came to the sad decision to close the branch down. However, a number of branch members have indicated they still wish to support the RNLI and will now do so via the Troon Branch. “This Branch is looking for new volunteers, soyou would like to help, please get in touch.” Ayr once had its own Leboat, stationed at Ayr Harbour in  under the management of Ayr Harbour Trust.   During the following  years a number of dferent Leboats were in service, one of which was built in Shadwell, London in  for just under pound. This was transported from London to Ayr Station by rail free of charge, by the London and North Western Railway Company. It was taken down Ayr High Street to Ayr Harbour and christened the ‘Janet Hoyle’, after the donor’s we. Eventually in  the RNLI Committee of Management decided to close the station as Troon had a motor Leboat where there was deemed a safer harbour entrance. There was then no RNLI presence in the town until the late ’s when a group of people decided to start a Fundraising Branch. title: familys new hope 85000 raised
story: NewsFamilys new hope as £, is raised to send son to America for cerebral palsy treatmentThe six-year-old will be heading to America after the huge sum of money was raised to fund his treatment.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  MAR NewsSaul with brothers Clay and Mylo and mum and dad, Karen and Stuart "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family’s bid to help their son walk again is set for take-off. Little Saul Wylie will travel to America for le-changing treatment on his severe form of cerebral palsy. The six-year-old, who weighed just lb at birth, has made the waiting list for pioneering surgery. There has been a massive charity effort across Ayrshire to fund the trip, with pound, raised in little over six months.Mum Karen, , told the Ayrshire Post : “To achieve this so quickly is beyond our wildest dreams.“We set a target of two years to get the money but the community reaction has been incredible.” Saul, of Tarbolton, has to go to the States because his aggressive condition is not treated on the NHS. The brave kid lives with spastic diplegia cerebral palsy, which affects his muscle tone and leaves him unable to walk unaided. Karen said: “Saul’s dream is to be able to stand by himself and take independent steps and maybe even one day walk around school with his friends. “Like every parent, we long for endless opportunities for our boy. “Saul is very happy and determined but we just want him to have the best opportunity at a better quality of le and to become as independent as possible.”  Medication, Botox, and even trampoline therapy have all been used to try and limit Saul’s pain. But his spot at St Louis Children’s Hospital in Missouri could be the ultimate answer. Karen said: “The operation is called selective dorsal rhizotomy, which will reduce Saul’s muscle stfness. “Added to intensive rehab, it will allow Saul to stand independently and potentially walk again. Unfortunately there is a waiting list for international patients so Saul’s surgery is not scheduled until . “But because we are in a position to go we have been put on their cancellation list and are keeping our fingers crossed.” Karen and husband Stuart have thrown themselves into a string of fundraising events with the ‘Steps For Saul’ campaign gathering momentum. Karen said: “We’ve done everything from coffee mornings to quiz nights and we can’t thank people enough for their response. “There have been skyes, race nights, sponsored cycles and I also did the Great Scottish Run. “People have taken Saul to their hearts and we’ve even had donations from as far afield as America, New Zealand, Canada and Ireland. “Hopefully he now has the chance he deserves.” • An open ice skate for Saul will take place at Ayr Ice Rink on Sunday, April , from -pm.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnDrugsCerebral palsyCharityAyr NewsAyr

story: NewsSleazy OAP, , who took pics of Ayr schoolgirls in mini-skirts told youre guilty all day longRetired architect Ross McKay was told by a sherf he "should be able to control" himself at his age.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsRoss Mackay was placed on the sex offenders register "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner who took pictures of schoolgirls in mini skirts will be on the sex offenders’ register for the next three years, writes Edwin Lawrence. Sleazy retired architect Ross McKay will also be kept under court supervision for the same period. McKay, , insisted he was innocent of the sordid behaviour but he was found guilty after a trial last month. Sherf John Montgomery told McKay: “You have been convicted of conduct which, in my estimation, contains a substantial sexual element and a signicant sexual aspect by clandestinely taking photos of female schoolgirls wearing short skirts. “At  years of age you really should be able to control yourself more appropriately than you have done by indulging in this sort of behaviour.” Sherf Montgomery warned McKay: “I detect an air of defiance from you, both at your trial and in what you have told the author of your criminal justice social work report. “My advice to you is keep a low profile. Do not put yourself in a position where it can be construed you have the aim of self-gratication.” Defence lawyer Gillian McBlane successfully argued against the imposition of a stringent sex offender prevention order against her client. This was requested by depute fiscal Vicky McMillan, and would have kept McKay out of public parks and well away from schools.   Ms McBlane said: “He is first offender and there is little to suggest he presents a signicant risk to the public.” Sherf Montgomery reminded her: “He continues to deny responsiblility.” But Ms McBlane maintained: “He very much recognises the authority of the court and he has assured me of his commitment to any order you might impose.” McKay, of Ardlochan Terrace in Maidens, insisted at his trial that he had not taken the photos of Belmont Academy schoolgirls in mini skirts that were found on his phone. title: selkirks-dagenham-drama-is-a-delight
story: THERES a red flag flying over the Victoria Hall this week.And dont be too surprised to see a burning bra or two hanging from the flagpole as well.Politics, profanities and a perfectly-sized piece of social history are being served up this week by the talented cast and crew of Selkirk Musical Theatre Company.Be warned though, Made in Dagenham is a steer away from the normal Victoria Hall productions.Peppered with sexual innuendo and shop-floor fs, its not exactly a family-friendly night at the opera.But it is a damn good show - and a foot-tapping reminder of the swinging sexism of the late s.For anyone who enjoys those wonderful kitchen-sink dramas of the decade - A Taste of Honey, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning, or Poor Cow - this is for you.Although, in fairness, at times it feels more Sid James than Shelagh Delaney as the humour and slapstick of Carry On provide plenty of laughs.And for anyone, like myself, who doesnt already know Made in Dagenham the Musical, dont despair... the songs, like the early Ford Cortinas, are instantly adorable.Kirsty Cleland has all the allure of a young Rita Tushingham as she enchants, enthrals and entertains in the lead role.As a strike-leader and long-suffering we, the Galashiels actress is both convincing and commanding.And the ever-reliable Stuart Mitchell, who plays hard-done-by husband Eddie, has to be at the top of his game not to be outshone.But, in true socialist fashion, Made in Dagenham the Musical isnt just about the leads... everyone has their part to play - and how well they play it.Tracy Borthwick is having a blast as the potty-mouthed Beryl.And Amanda Blacklock is pitch perfect as the hapless Clare who attempts to keep up with the flow of double-entendres.Ellen McFadzen, with her Viv Nicholson hair-style and shortening mini-skirts, is a delight as sassy Sandra.And the shopfloor resolve is perfectly pitched by Ellen Halliday, as Cassie, and Julie Craig, as Connie.Relationships, friendships and even governments are tested in this factual story which, historically, helped females eventually earn an equal footing when it came to filling up pay packets.Robin Murray could challenge Mike Yarwood with his hilarious performance as Harold Wilson.And hes regularly brought down a peg or two by the feisty Rachel Inglis as Barbara Castle.Made in Dagenham the Musical is a battle of the classes as much as the sexes, with Jodie Millar and Yvonne Mitchell providing some gentried grace.The dialogue is a delight, the foot-to-the-floor pace is perfect, and the choreography, costumes, straight from Carnaby Street, and score makes sure this is a production that will strike a chord for decades to come.But for any musical production to be a success, it needs songs.From the brilliant opening scene, this show doesnt disappoint.Busy Women, Everybody Out and Viva Eastbourne are nothing other than tremendous encore numbers that bring out the very best of this talented cast.But perhaps the highlights are Julie Craigs sensational take on the riveting Same Old Story, Rachel Inglis reaching the high notes in the incredible Ideal World, and the delightful duet of Stuart Mitchell and Kirsty Cleland with the making-up masterpiece Im Sorry, I Love You.Made in Dagenham the Musical is a celebration of women fighting for their rights.While it succeeds, this move away from the comfort zone is more of a testament to just how good Selkirk Musical Theatre Company has become.If you havent yet got your tickets... join the picket line quickly and dont be disappointed.Made in Dagenham the title: anniversary-celebrations-to-bring-hogg-back-into-fashion
story: NEXT year marks the th anniversary of Borders poet James Hoggrsquos birth and plans to mark the milestone are underway.And it is hoped the celebrations will bring the self-taught novelist back to the fore.Dr Adrian Hunter of Stirling University is joining forces with the Ettrick and Yarrow Community Development Companyto honour the Ettrick Shepherd.Hogg was born in the Ettrick Valley and worked almost all of his le as a shepherd.His best-known works include The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a Justied Sinner in , and two years earlier The Three Perils of Man: or War, Women and Witchcraft.The Ettrick Shepherd became internationally known during the th century.He had  volumes published during his letime and was well-known on both sides of the Atlantic.Hogg was popular amongst academics, especially in North America, with many of them circulating his books.In British and Scottish literature, he is highly regarded, however, over time awareness of his work has decreased.It is hoped the anniversary celebrations will recty this by promoting his work as well as drawing Hogg enthusiasts to the region from across the UK.Dr Adrian Hunter is a senior lecturer of English Studies at Stirling university.His role within the Hogg society is to raise public awareness of the poet.Dr Hunter told us: ldquoIt is really important to celebrate James Hogg as he is one of the great literary geniuses of the th century whose work is just as relevant now as it once was.ldquoHogg was an equal to poets in his day and by celebrating this anniversary we hope to raise him to the same level of recognition as Burns and Scott.ldquoWe are in conversation with writers and performers from across the Borders and want a big emphasise on his music, as it was a major part of Hoggrsquos work.ldquoThis event has great potential to boost local tourism by bringing people to the Borders to celebrate the le of Hogg."Hogg has many connections across the Borders that the team hope to emphasize.His local pub was the Gordon Arms hotel in the Yarrow Valley, and he was one the founders of the St Ronans Border Games which have been held every July since .The James Hogg exhibition in the Ettrick Valley, which contains many artefacts and originals donated by Lady Steel of Aikwood, and the Hogg monument at St Maryrsquos Loch have been celebrating the Ettrick Shepherdrsquos le for many years.The Borders celebrations will take place over  to mark the anniversary. No concrete dates have been set as the event is still being finalised. However, local people and businesses are encouraged to get involved to help promote Hoggrsquos Borders legacy.Internationally, the anniversary will be celebrated in Washington DC.Enthusiasts can attend an event held in the Library of Congress where they will be talking about Hoggrsquos le and Borderrsquos traditions.Stirling University is known as the world centre of Hoggs work.And they are currently doing a project to collect all the poets work and republish it. So far,  volumes of Hoggrsquos work have been collected, and  have been published.The project started in the mid s and the estimated finishing date wonrsquot be till .The programme of events is still in the planning stage and the organisers are currently raising money to hold the celebrations around the Borders and in Stirling.They are currently applying to ious sources for a six-figure sum to honour the literary great.If you would like to get involved or find out any more information, then contact Dr Adrian Hunter at adrian.hunter@stir.ac.uk or EYCDC Vicky Davidson at vicky@ettrickandyarrow.org.uk

title: glendinning-gets-fizzy-with-touring-science-show
story: MINI scientists from Glendinning Primary School grabbed their safety goggles last week to make their own fizzing potions.Primary one to three pupils got an introduction into chemistry when Generation Science visited their school on Thursday.They took part in the Get Fizzy workshop and served up some mysterious mixtures.Generation Science is a touring programme of fun science shows for younger children.And is delivered by Edinburgh Science, the international educational charity who aim to deliver the wonder of science to people around the world.The workshop was sponsored by EDF Renewables who are supporting a iety of Generation Science events across Scotland.Leanne Watson of EDF Renewables said: ldquoWe are proud to support Generation Science.ldquoThese fun and interactive workshops are an engaging way to encourage a new generation of scientists, who will be at the forefront of developing renewable energy and new technologies.Get Fizzy is a chemistry workshop for beginners where pupils learn about solids, liquids, gases and fizzes and how they can react.Acting Head Teacher of Glendinning Primary School, Nichola McCall, told us: ldquoWe were delighted to welcome the Generation Science tour to the school.ldquoGet Fizzy is a hands-on workshop that makes science fun and enjoyable."For some of our pupils, it was very exciting as it was their first ever introduction to chemistry.Over the last  years Generation Science has reached over one million pupils in Scotland.This year the tour will visit over  schools in  local authority areas from the Borders to the Shetland Isles.Get Fizzy is one of  educational shows and workshops provided by Generation Science and powered by EDF Energy.They are designed to make science exciting and easy to understand to help teachers cover the school science curriculum.

story: A -year-old Selkirk man has been remanded in custody at the towns sherf court after being accused of stealing alcohol from a shop he was already banned from.James Birchall is charged with stealing three bottles of spirits from the Co-operative store in High Street, Selkirk, on Tuesday and breaching his bail conditions.He appeared from custody and pleaded not guilty to both charges.A trial date has been fixed for next month and Birchall was remanded in custody by Sherf Peter Paterson after no application was made for bail.

title: theyre-game-for-a-laugh-at-sainsburys
story: SHOPPERS are in for a laugh when they visit Sainsburys in lead up to Comic Relief.Throughout much of March customers will have the opportunity to join staff in sporting a red nose.And it has nothing to do with catching a cold.Comic Relief is ing to the supermarket chain to celebrate a  year partnership.The milestone will be marked in the Peebles branch with a number of fundraising events in the run-up to Red Nose Day.As well as a tombola, fancy dress and customer car wash, staff will be selling red noses to raise money for the charity.Customer trading manager Margot Swanston said: ldquoWe in Peebles Sainsburyrsquos love to be involved in Red Nose Day."We have a whole week of activities planned to raise money in store."We kick off with a quiz night and we are also holding a bake sale which all the budding bakers amongst our staff are helping with. Tombola and lsquoguess the weight of the cakersquo are also planned in.And customers wonrsquot see staff in their usual unorm on the main Friday either, as they will be decked out in a colourful array of fancy dress costumes.Margot added: ldquoWe are holding a car wash and a lsquobeat the manager challengersquo which will involve an Xbox gaming competition which Irsquom sure will be eagerly contested.Store Manager David Duncan added: ldquoWersquore really passionate about supporting this great cause and hope our customers continue to get involved and help support our exciting fundraising activities.

title: intriguing-new-additions-for-the-sir-walter-collection-at-abbotsford
story: NEW additions are being included to the intriguing Sir Walter Scott exhibition at Abbotsford.A wooden Jacobite quaich, a rare pack of th century playing cards, a slop bowl and a Persian charm are among a range of new items added to the exhibition, which went on show from Friday.The Jacobite quaich belonged to Sir Walterrsquos great grandfather, Walter lsquoBeardiersquo Scott.Beardie fought for the Jacobite cause and famously vowed not to trim his beard until a Stuart monarch regained the throne.Also new to the exhibition is a copy of Adam Smithrsquos Wealth of Nations, which Scott used as a student at Edinburgh University.Visitors only have a limited time to see a gold memorial locket, set with semi-precious stones spelling out the author name as an acrostic poem.The piece will be ing to the private lender in May, alongside a silver centrepiece commemorating the th anniversary of Scottrsquos poem The Lady of the Lake.Kirsty Archer-Thompson, Abbotsfordrsquos collections and interpretation manager, said: ldquoOur introductory exhibition to the le and legacy of Sir Walter Scott is refreshed every year, so there is always something new for visitors to see.ldquoThis year we have added an extensive mix of items ranging from family heirlooms and some of Scottrsquos favourite books, to more exotic items like the Persian amulet.ldquoWe are also looking forward to making further changes this year, when we will be loaned an exciting range of items from the National Museum of Scotland later in the Spring, so itrsquos worth people coming back for another look in a few months.The free exhibition will be open daily to visitors from March .Visitors can go see the exhibition from am to pm.

title: campaigners-call-time-on-single-use-pint-pots-at-borders-events
story: CAMPAIGNERS are calling for pint pot deposit schemes at public events in the Scottish Borders.Tom Rawson of Plastic Free Melrose said the group is fighting to cut back on plastic use in the town.And one of the suggestions is to get revellers to buy a re-useable cup at gatherings such as the Rugby Sevens tournament.At the local community council meeting last week, he said: ldquoPlastic usage is a huge issue everywhere.ldquoAnd I think it is embarrassing as a society that we have such a problem.ldquoWe want to look at stopping this problem. One of the ways is by going into local businesses to encourage them to cut down on what they use.ldquoAn idea we have also had is introducing a pint deposit scheme, similar to the one which is in place at Murrayfield.ldquoThat is something we could look at bringing to Melrose at events such as the Rugby Sevens to cut down on single use plastic. Everyone pays for one pint pot and it is reused, rather than just thrown away.The Scottish Government is also currently shaping a lsquodepositschemersquo for drinks containers following positive feedback in a public consultation.If brought in, it would see consumers reclaim a percentage of the cost of every plastic bottle they recycle.A similar scheme has also been introduced in Norway.Val Miller, vice chairwoman of Melrose Community Council said: ldquoPlastic Free Melrose can take our support as a given.ldquoThere is so much plastic these days. Most of what you buy in the supermarket is pre-packed, no matter how much you try to get away from it.Campaigners have also been working with local schoolchildren to teach them about plastic pollution.And the group recently organised a litter pick around the town.Mr Rawson said: ldquoThe issue needs to be stopped at its source.ldquoIf your bath is overflowing, you donrsquot just pull the plug out ndash you turn the taps off. That is how we can change things, by encouraging people not to use as much.

title: bus-passenger-ordered-to-pay-compensation
story: A -year-old who was abusive towards a bus driverhas been ordered to pay a total of pound at Selkirk Sherf Court.Richard Tindall of Gala Park Gardens, Galashiels, was fined pound for behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on board the bus in Abbotsford Road, Galashiels, on June .And he was told to pay pound compensation to the driver.A video of the incident was played in the courtroom which showed Tindall abusing the driver and then after leaving the bus re-boarded to continue the onslaught.A female passenger was heard to protest when Tindall said, get out this country and go back to where you came from among other obscenities.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said there was no screen guarding the drivers compartment so he was a sitting duck in his seat.He continued: "The accused was trying to get off the bus and there was a dispute about the fare."He was trying to force open the doors in the company of his young daughter at the time."He was using words such as scumbag, idiot and stick it up your a***."As the video shows the accused came back on the bus to continue the abuse."People should not be exposed to this kind of behaviour in the course of their employment."Defence lawyer Joe Boyd described it as an unsavoury incident.He explained that his client had got on the bus with his young daughter who had immediately ran up to the back of the bus which had annoyed the driver.Mr Boyd said that Tindall had suffered a traumatic brain injury in October  which sometimes causes him to react to situations.He said: "He can be the most pleasant of characters but the next minute he can descend into something of the opposite."

title: selkirk-woman-denies-three-offences-against-ex-partner
story: A SELKIRK woman faces three charges at the towns sherf court in connection with her former partner.Twenty five year old Leigha Mitchell, of Montrose Place, is accused of breaching her bail conditions by approaching and contacting Andrew Stewart at his home on January  and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner.She also denies struggling violently with her former partner and refusing to leave his home on August  last year.A trial date has been fixed for May  with an intermediate hearing on April .

title: folk-stars-megan-and-findlay-bring-science-to-hawick
story: ITS one of the most anticipated releases in folk music.And for a sneak preview of Megan Henwood and Findlay Napiers The Story Song Scientist, they will play in the Borders.Back in , Megan won the BBC Young Folk Award, aged just , alongside her brother Joe.Since then, she has gone on to become a formidable British talent.And in  she embarked on her first sold-out headline UK tour ahead of her third and finest album to date lsquoRiverrsquo.More recently though Megan has teamed up with one of the finest songwriters and storytellers of the contemporary Scottish folk scene.Findlay Napier is an insurgent talent who made his name touring and recording with multi-award winning traditional Scottish folk band Back of the Moon.In his more recent projects his song-writing took centre stage and was described by The Sunday Herald as genuine songcraft and wit following in the Dford  Tilbrook tradition.Findlay is also well known as the host of Celtic Connectionsrsquo Late Night Sessions and for his Hazy Recollections concert series which showcases the very best in new roots music.Megan and Findlay met a songwriting retreat in  in Aldeburgh, Suffolk, run by the English Folk and Dance Song Society and co-wrote some songs together which resulted in the forthcoming EP.The Story Song Scientist will be released on Dharma Records on March .And just a few days earlier - Monday, March  to be precise - they will play together at the String Theory club night in Hawick.Ticketsare available on the door.

title: pentlands-activity-camps-is-looking-for-volunteers
story: This weekrsquos feature from Tweeddale Volunteers focuses on volunteer opportunities for older teenagers ndash at Pentlands Activity Camps.Wanted: volunteers age +... Want to spend your holidays in the great outdoors, learning new skills and having fun Pentlands Activity Camps offers multi-activity and specialist day camps for school age children during the holidays ndash based in the woods and fields of Netherurd and Broomlee, local outdoor centres.Established in , PAC offers older teenagersand young adults the opportunity to develop work and le skills with children by volunteering as an assistant leader at one of our camps.Your role would be to support a group leader to plan, organise and lead a iety of outdoor and indoor activities ndash anything from playing lsquokick the canrsquo to building dens in the woods, junk boat racing to capture the flag, rounders to baking. Itrsquos a lot of fun and all you need is lots of energy, enthusiasm and a willingness to run about, get stuck in and make sure the children have a great time.Inyou get your lunch, and lots of cups of tea, coffee or hot chocolate. We also offer coaching and mentoring as well as references for job, gap year and UCAS applications. You can sign up for the Saltire award ndash after a week at PAC yoursquoll have clocked up  hours.But the main thing about volunteering with us at PAC is the fun you will have. Itrsquos a great way to spend a week of your holidays ndash being outdoors, making new friends, being part of a small staff team and getting to know lots of great children. And itrsquos a great opportunityyou are thinking of working with children or adults in the future ndash you can find out whether itrsquos for you.PAC volunteers come back year on year and the majority of our staff have once been volunteer assistant leaders, and many came to PAC as children. That could be you. Interested  Then contact Lindsay Mann on   or email info@pentlandsactivitycamps or check out our website to get a flavour of what we do www.pentlandsactivitycamps

title: band-hoping-to-bag-a-boost-for-new-uniform
story: ST RONANrsquoS Silver Band is hoping to bag a cash boost to help buy new unorms.The group has been shortlisted for cash from the Tesco Bags of Help community funding initiative.But its up to shoppers to decide where the money goes.And members at St Ronans are calling on Peeblesshire to get behind them so they can raise pound, to replace their concert jackets and outdoor engagement unorms ndash which date back to .The money would also be used to help kit out the younger members in the Future Band.Band secretary Keith Belleville told us: "We are delighted to have been selected as one of the Bags of Help groups during March and April this year."Our new unorm appeal is an ambitious project to kit the whole band organisation out and all  members will benefit, as well the public who listen to and watch the band at our many engagements across the year."We hope that customers in the Peebles Tesco Store will cast their votes to help us achieve this goal."Grants of pound,, pound, and pound, are offered as part of the Tesco scheme.The cash is raised through carrier bag sales and customers can choose which projects should be rewarded, buy casting their vote using a blue token which is given at the checkout each time they shop.The Bags of Help project has already delivered over pound million to more than , projects across Britain.Tony McElroy from Tesco, said: "Bags of Help has been a fantastic success and wersquove been overwhelmed by the response from customers."Itrsquos such a special scheme because itrsquos local people who decide how the money will be spent in their community."There are some fantastic projects on the shortlists and we canrsquot wait to see these come to le in hundreds of communities."Customers will be able to vote for the band at the Peebles store between March  and April  at the Peebles store.To find out more about the scheme and how to nominate a project, visit www.tesco bagsofhelp

title: borders-young-musicians-have-plenty-to-blow-about
story: SOME of the best young Borders musicians are set to showcase their talents later this month in Melrose.The Scottish Borders Wind Orchestra, the Borders Chamber Orchestra, the Guitar Ensemble and the Junior Wind Band will all perform at the concert on Monday, March .The performances in Melrose Parish Church have been organised by Scottish Borders Councils Instrumental Music Service.Building on the success of a similar sell-out event held last year, the young musicians, who represent all of the regionrsquos high schools and many of the primaries, will play a wide iety pieces ranging from traditional Scottish through to works by th century Italian composer Palestrina, Abba and Boney M.Local councillor Euan Jardine, who is the spokesman for Culture and Sport at the local authority, said: ldquoIf last yearrsquos event is anything to go by, this promises to be another impressive performance that will give these young musicians the opportunity to showcase their talent and skills in a spectacular way."I would imagine that tickets will disappear quickly so would encourage people to arrive early get themselves a seat so they are able to enjoy what I am sure will be an extremely memorable event.Following this years concert, the Instrumental Music Service will begin recruiting for their next session and are on the lookout for young instrumentalists interested in joining a music ensemble.As well as being able to develop ensemble and performing skills, pupils get the chance to take part in courses and residential weekends supported by the PTA Borders Young Musicians.A range of social activities are also provided along with the opportunity to make new friends.Ticketsfor the Melrose Parish Church concert are available at the door - pound each or pound for concessions.

title: les-mis-stars-shine-in-hawick
story: STARS of the hit musical Les Miseacuterables thrilled a packed Hawick Town Hall last week.Recreating West End and Broadway musical hit songs with amazing authenticity, this cast of past principal performers from Les Miseacuterables presented a blockbusting two-hour show that is considered to be the UKrsquos favourite musical theatre concert.The performance featured David FawcettAndy Reiss , who is also the resident director for the national tour of Les Miseacuterables, Shona Lindsayand Poppy Tierney , together with a live band, brilliantly captured the feel of the original orchestrations of the chosen musicals.Organisers and promoters. Live Borders, hope the Beyond the Barricade show will lure music lovers back to similar events.Events and programming officer Hamish Moir told us: ldquoWhat an amazing night!"A huge thanks to everyone who joined us for what was a journey through some of the greatest stage musicals including Miss Saigon, Phantom of the Opera, Blood Brothers, The Lion King, Hamilton and, of course, Les Miseacuterables."It was a brilliant atmosphere in Hawick Town Hall and we hope the audience enjoyed it as much as the Live Bordersrsquo team."I would highly recommend checking out our future events programme.

title: get-a-life-arrives-in-the-borders
story: ACCLAIMED Scottish actors John Shedden and Finlay McLean are set to perform a series of weird and wonderful sketches later this month at Bowhill House Theatre, near Selkirk.Audiences will meet a iety of hilarious characters from the land of the living - and the dead.Get a Le! is written by playwright and novelist David Henry WilsonJudge the judge, be starstruck by the astronomer, eavesdrop on the Prime Minister and the President, and witness two extraordinary interviews as Hamlet and Shylockto rewrite their stories!You can even throw your undies at Wolf Humperhoven!Out of this kaleidoscope of theatre, social satire, politics and parody, emerges a startling view of the crazy world we live in!Finlay McLean has worked extensively in theatre, radio, TV and film.On television he has appeared in numerous dramas including: Rebus, Taggart, Rab C Nesbitt, Waterloo Road, Lovesick and Burnistoun.Shetland born, John Sheddens distinguished career in broadcasting and theatre embraces everything from Shakespeare, Chekhov, Pinter, Beckett to solo Fringe First winning plays Every Inch a King.He created the role of Stan Laurel in Mr Laurel and Mr Hardy which transferred from the Traverse to the Mayfair, London.Their not altogether crazy look at a crazy world arrives at Bowhill on Thursday, March .Ticketsfor the show, which starts at pm, are pound and pound for under s.

title: off-duty-cop-accused-of-causing-disturbance-at-borders-hotel
story: A POLICE officer has been accused of causing a disturbance in a Kelso hotel.Pierce Solley is alleged to have produced a police warrant card despite being off duty and intimidate bar staff and challenge others to fight at the Cross keys Hotel on October .It is claimed he refused to leave when asked to do so by event organisers and police officers and behaved in an aggressive and intimidating manner towards customers and staff.The -year-old, whose address was given as c o Police Scotlands Professional Standards Department at Fettes in Edinburgh,pleaded not guilty at Jedburgh Sherf Court to a charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner.A trial date has been fixed for March .

title: getting-checked-could-save-your-life
story: A NEW campaign has been launched to encourage people to get checked for cancer.With research highlighting that fear of a potential cancer diagnosis continues to stop people acting, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Survivors campaign aims to illustrate that more people are surviving cancer than ever before, and highlight that getting checked early plays a big part.People are being encouraged to join the movement by sharing what a loved onersquos cancer survival has meant to them, using #MySurvivor in a bid to tell the other side of the story.For more information visit getcheckedearly.org.

title: biggest-parents-evening-comes-to-the-borders
story: A pathway organisation that helps school pupils in the Borders find careers and jobs is hosting the Biggest Parents Evening in Galashiels this week.Developing the Young Workforce Borders are one of  regional groups working in partnership with local employers to showcase apprenticeship and career opportunities as part of Scottish Apprenticeship Week.The local DYW Borders event will be held at Job Centre Plus, Galashiels on Wednesday .The live jobs fair features full-time, part-time and apprenticeship opportunities as well as a CV workshop and information on the SQA Qualications and the apprenticeship family.Sara Ward, Programme Manager with DYW Borders, told us: "The event will provide an understanding of the apprenticeship family while getting rid of the myths and misconceptions."Hosted in partnership with Skills Development Scotland, Borders College and Jobcentre Plus the aim of the event is to promote the fantastic local career opportunities and help parents and carers understand why they should encourage more young people in choosing an apprenticeship in the Scottish Borders."National and local organisations who have already signed up to promote their opportunities at the Biggest Parents Evening include NHS Borders, Oregon Timber, Scottish Borders Council, Works+, McDonald Cardrona Hotel, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, Mears Group, Encompass and many more.Sara added: "The event will not only demonstrate a clear commitment from employers to showcase the great opportunities that are available locally but raise the profile of those committed to Developing the Young Workforce."We are very aware that parents are the biggest influencers in a childrsquos career path, therefore we aim to influence the influencers."The event, which runs from pm to pm, is open parents and pupils

title: jim-clark-rally-could-return-this-spring
story: ORGANISERS of the Jim Clark Rally are confident the race willto the roads of the Borders this spring.And they have pencilled in the weekend of May  and .The rally has not taken place since the tragic deaths of three people in .Elizabeth Allan, , Iain Provan, , and Len Stern, , were all killed as a car left the road near Coldstream.Major reviews have since taken place into safety surrounding closed road rally events as well as a fatal accident enquiry.The Scottish Government is now looking at afor both the Jim Clark Rally and the Isle of Mull Rally by bringing legislation into line with the other parts of the UK.A spokesman for the Jim Clark Rally told us: "We have been maintaining contact and continued working with Scottish Borders Council and Police Scotland in hopeful anticipation that rallying couldsooner rather than later."Arrangements and plans are already in place to facilitate a quick resumption of the sport on completion of the parliamentary process."Potential rally competitors, officials, volunteers and fans right across the UK are therefore advised to pencil in two important dates, May  and  , and plan their routes to the eastern Scottish Borders."With a bit of luck and goodwill, it should soon be possible to allow all those interested to confirm their diary date in ink."The recently concluded Public Consultation by the government on the new proposals proved there was an overwhelming desire for awith  percent of all replies being positive.

title: extending-borders-railway-among-21-options-to-improve-transport
story: EXTENDING the Borders Railway line and putting on extra buses to the BGH are two of the options being considered to help shape the future of transport in the region.In a report published today, The Borders Transport Corridors Study outlined  options that could bring benefits to the area.And they include proposals for better bus links to health centres and neighbouring cities as well as the partial dualling of the A and A roads.Cabinet secretary for transport, infrastructure and connectivity Michael Matheson said: "The Borders Transport Corridors Study fulfils our commitment to consider the future transport needs of the area."We have already committed to rail stations at East Linton and Reston and these will be delivered as part of work to improve capacity to Edinburgh. We will now go on to consider a further twenty-one options as part of the Strategic Transport Projects Review , which is being taken forward during the letime of this Parliament.ldquoThe Projects Review is a nationwide appraisal to identy where improvements are needed and guide investment in Scotlandrsquos transport infrastructure over the next two decades."The recommendations made in this study ndash which are underpinned by detailed evidence on problems and opportunities ndash will help ensure the case is made for improvements in The Borders."We look forward to building on the successful partnerships that we have developed as part of the study as we move forward with the next stage of this important work."
