title: msp-writes-to-minister-opposing-housing-plans-by-dirleton-castle
story: Michelle Ballantyne, South Scotland MSP, has written to Scottish housing minister Kevin Stewart MSP urging him to throw out the proposals for the village of Dirleton.She said the plans, which would see  homes built at Castlemains Farm, to the east of Dirleton Castle, could lead to a reduction in the ldquomany tourists who visit the medieval fortress.The castle is one of East Lothianrsquos top five visitor attractions and dates back to the th century.In a letter to Mr Stewart, Conservative Ms Ballantyne said: ldquoDirleton attracts many tourists, particularly during the summer. The inclusion of a development which is out of step with the rest of the villagersquos architectural character could cause a reduction in visitor numbers.Developer Queensberry Properties Ltd was refused planning permission to build the houses by East Lothian councillors in September. It lodged an appeal with the Scottish Government after councillors voted against the advice of their own planning officers.In her letter to Mr Stewart, Ms Ballantynesays there is ldquooverwhelming local opposition to the plans and urges him to fully engage with local residents to ensure their voices are heard.She said: ldquo written objections were lodged with the council and only one representation of support. This matches with what I have seen on the ground. At a street surgery this was the number one issue raised.ldquoDirleton is an exceptionally beautul village with a th-century castle of national historic importance. There are few villages such as Dirleton in south Scotland and it would be a shame to rush into a development which could be much more considerate of the surrounding history and community.

title: five-out-of-six-electric-vehicle-charging-points-at-east-lothian-stations-not-working
story: Only the charging point at Drem Railway Station is back in action.The delays in bringing the charging points back into public use have been described as ldquodisappointingby East Lothian MSP Iain Gray.And Councillor Norman Hampshire, deputy leader of East Lothian Council, said moves to encourage people to buy electric cars could be hampered by the lack of working charging points.Mr Hampshire said the council had received numerous complaints about the out-of-order points at train stations.The council is currently working on an ambitious project to provide its own charging points not only in town centres but in villages and more rural locations as it strives to meet national targets.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoWe have received many complaints about the failure of this provision at all our train stations.ldquoIt has been taken up with Scot Rail on several occasions but no progress has been made.ldquoEast Lothian Council is working with the Scottish Government to deliver the new charging points and are stressing to them the importance of funding to deliver a high maintenance standard.ldquoWe will not give people the confidence to purchase an electric vehiclethey see many charging points with Out of Order signs on them.ScotRail said it lsquodecommissionedrsquo all its charging points across Scotland in May last year after a wiring fault was discovered at Pitlochry Station.At the time, the train operator said it hoped to have the points back in use in six weeks but a spokesperson, confirmed only  of ScotRailrsquos  chargers were in service, but they hoped to have the others back working in the spring.MSP Mr Gray said: ldquoWith the number of electric vehicles on our roads growing year on year, it is vital that owners have access to charging points in places that are convenient for them.ldquoTrain stations are an obvious place to help facilitate a joined-up approach to travel, so itrsquos certainly disappointing that so many charging points at East Lothian stations are out of order.ldquoI have already raised this with ScotRail and believe they should make it a priority to have them back up and running again as quickly as possible.A ScotRail spokesperson said: ldquoWe apologise to customers currently unable to charge their electric cars. We are working with our contractor to have our charge points back in service as quickly as possible.

title: cockburnspath-woman-meets-her-stem-cell-donor-on-itv-show
story: Laura Regan received a bone marrow transplant in  from an anonymous stem cell donor after being diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.Laura said that she thought about her donor often, adding: ldquoI knew it wouldnrsquot have been easy for him, having to re-arrange their le around the transplant.The -year-old was discovered by the ITV show This Time Next Year through her blog, in which she records the stages of her recovery.They filmed her saying that she would find her donor and they would appear on the show together a year later ndash which she did.The donor was a -year-old doctor named Simon Bird, and to her surprise they ended up living close to each other in London.ldquoThe first thing I did when I got Simonrsquos details was to look up his address on Google Maps," Laura said."It turned out that he lived just three miles away!ldquoEvery one of my friends told me I would be in tears but on the night, I couldnrsquot stop smiling."Simon was everything Irsquod hoped and imagined in real le and I was just so grateful to him for what hersquod done.ldquoWe were both keen to do the show to raise awareness for the Anthony Nolan Charity, who had helped me find a donor in the first place."Following filming, the pair have kept in touch. Laura said: ldquoWersquove been out for drinks. Wersquore both in long-term relationships, and Simon and his partner have invited me and my partner over for dinner. Wersquove become close.The episode, hosted by Davina McCall, will be aired tomorrowat .pm.

title: east-lothian-council-services-for-hire
story: The council is looking at ways to bring in extra revenue in the next three years by capitalising on its services and the influx of new housing in the county.Burial plots in two new cemeteries will be made available for advance sales as the council re-opens the pre-sale of lairs in Dunbar and Prestonpans, where capacity issues have seen the practice suspended in recent years. New housing developments in the towns have seen plans put forward for new graveyards to cope with the increasing populations.In Prestonpans, a proposed cemetery is included with plans to build  houses at Dolphingstone Farm while in Dunbar plans for a new graveyard at Newtonlees have been approved by the council.A council spokesperson said advance sales were withdrawn in the towns to ensure lairs were available for immediate need as they ran out of space.However, he confirmed: ldquoIt is expected that, as the new provision opens in Prestonpans and Dunbar, we will be in a position to process requests.As further new sites are developed, it is anticipated this option will become more widely available.It is anticipated the move will bring an additional pound, in revenue for the local authority in the next financial year as people queue up to book plots in their home towns.The move is one of a number of ventures which have been given the go-ahead in the councilrsquos budget plans for the next three years to maximise income.It also includes plans to bid to take over factoring contracts for landscaping in new housing developments and offer to install play equipment and areas in the same estates.The local authority is looking to capitalise on the influx of housing into the county, which is seeing up to , new homes being built across its communities.It hopes that it can compete with private factoring firms to take on responsibility for public areas within new housing estates, which developers traditionally hand on to independent factors.And it has budgeted a potential income of up to pound, by providing the commercial service over the next three years, as well as a further pound, by offering to install play areas in the new developments.The council said it was seeking to develop ldquocommercial opportunities across all services.The spokesman said: ldquoGiven the countyrsquos growth agenda, these are areas that we intend to explore.

title: glasgow-school-one-of-the-last-private-girls-secondaries-in-scotland-to-close
story: Craigholme School, on the South Side, will shut its doors in August after being unable to resolve financial dficulties.Last year, the school joined forces with Kelvinside Academy, in the West End, in a bid to survive, but under a formal merger the school will now close in August.All pupils will be transferred to Kelvinside to complete their secondary education, although the fate of staff is more uncertain.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesTeachers may face redundancies unless new positions can be found at Kelvinside.The primary school at Craigholme, which accepts both boys and girls, will remain open as a feeder school for Kelvinside.The closure comes at a dficult time for private schools with steadily falling pupil rolls across the sector following the financial crash of .Since then fees have risen by more than  per cent, with the average annual cost to families climbing from some pound, to its current figure of around pound,. Fees at Craigholme topped pound, a year.The closure also marks another blow for single sex education in Scotland. There are now only four private girlsrsquo secondary schools left and one in the state sector.Craigholme hit the headlines in  when it emerged former pupil Aqsa Mahmood had dropped out of university to join Islamic State in Syria, where she was believed to have married an ISIS fighter.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesDonald Wilson, chair of the board of governors at Kelvinside Academy and Craigholme School, said the closure of the senior school would now follow the merger.Mr Wilson confirmed pupil numbers at Craigholme had dropped signicantly in recent years, while the impending impact of the Barclay Review, which will see removal of business rates relief, and other financial pressures, presented signicant challenges to all independent schools in Scotland.It has not yet been decided whether the facilities and land owned by the school will be sold off or retained for use by Kelvinside.Craigholme was founded in  by Jessie Murdoch as Pollokshields Ladiesrsquo School. The school had forty pupils on the roll and was housed at Dalziel Drive in a villa named Craigholme.The schoolrsquos name was changed after the First World War to Craigholme School. Recent expansion has included a pound million PE facility on the schoolrsquos playing fields at Pollok Park.In recent years pupil rolls have fallen. In   there were nearly  pupils at the school, but this fell to  in   and  in   and  this year.Read more of todays top Glasgow stories

title: the-ultimate-packing-list-for-2019
story: Read on for our list of the best and most efficient things to pack no matter where in the world you are getting away to this year. Whether you are a sun worshipper, a continent hopper or a snow seeker try out these tips and tricks to get your packing down to a fine art.*On some occasions, we earn revenue from content. This commercial content is compiled via expert opinion. Clicking on certain hyperlinks within this article will redirect you to a rd party.The BasicsWe are all guilty of packing much more than we need when it comes to holidays ndash does anyone  feel the need to pack enough underwear so that you could wear three pairs a day and still have some spares Get ready to go Credit: PixabayA good rule of thumb to keep in mind when packing minimally is that  of an item is the most that you will need when you have access to washing facilities .Look up packing lists, and you can easily get overwhelmed. Before you e into all the details, remember that what you need can be easily broken down into six categories:Tricks to Pack Like a ProBefore you start pulling all your favourite clothes out of your wardrobe and throwing them into the nearest suitcase, take a moment to try these packing hacks that will save you space and help you get the most out of even the smallest bag.What will you take  Credit: Lum, PixabayWhat to take to sunny spotsIf you are hitting the beach or looking to soak up the rays on a sun holiday* keeping cool and looking stylish are often top of the list.While itrsquos tempting to take only shorts and skimpy t-shirts donrsquot forget to take some long sleeved options in both tops and bottoms- they are ideal for protecting you or giving you a break from the sun, not to mention thwarting annoying insect bites.Hit the beach Credit: Pexels, PixabayA well-packed suitcase should have:The big one to remember when heading away to soak up some sun is, of course, to bring plenty of sunblock with you!Remember to apply it to ALL exposed skin nothing will set you apart from the crowd quite like having sunburn in the exact pattern of that funky nettop that you thought would be the ideal way to keep cool.Getaways to colder climesGet smart when yoursquore packing for cold weather and give serious thought to what you can wear rather than pack. Large jackets, chunky scarfs and heavy boots take up so much space in a suitcase that you are better off wearing them while travelling instead and just popping your coat in the overhead bin.Be prepared fro colder weather Credit: Stock Snap, PixabayMake sure to pack:Thermals are a le saver when it comes to making the most of limited packing space. A thermal vest and long johns will instantly transform almost any outfit into one fit for colder climes with minimum fuss.Weekend AdventuresMake the most of a long weekend with a trip away from your usual haunts. When it comes to packing for short term trips less is more.Where will your weekend take you  Credit: Roger Yo Santos Dias, PixabayBeing away for only a few days means you can easily plan out what you are going to wear on each day. It is also the best way to ensure you donrsquot overpack.Make sure to pack:If you are looking to save space when packing for a weekend getaway bear in mind that basic toiletries are often available at hotels. Alternatively, get your hands on refillable travel size bottles* so you only end up taking what you need instead of that massive sized bottle of shampoo!Time to enjoy your holidayNow that you have your packing planned out itrsquos time to get back to the serious business of deciding what you are going to get up to during your next adventure!Get out there and see the world Credit: Hans, PixabayWill you be heading out to tick off sightseeing spots , or is it going to be all about taking some rest and relaxation on this trip However you decide to spend your getaway, follow these packing tips, and you will be perfectly prepared!

title: 100k-budgets-1500-guests-and-6000-flowers-behind-the-lavish-world-of-asian-weddings-in-glasgow
story: This is the glamorous heart of Asian wedding planning in Glasgow, of which the staff have become the stars of new BBC Scotland reality series ldquoGetting Hitched Asian Style, set to give ldquoMy Big Fat Gypsy Wedding a run for its money.Hassan Anwar is the managing director of Saffron Events, one of the UKrsquos most established and respected Asian event management and catering companies.Hassan Anwar, managing director of Saffron Events in DalmarnockThe -year-old, from Crookston, runs a tight ship, despite having organised around  weddings in  - his busiest year yet in  years of wedding planning.Asian weddings are known to rumble on for days and the series explores the four main events involved in a Pakistani-Muslim wedding: the mehndi, an amusing and colourful night involving intricate henna designs, the nikah, which is the official Islamic wedding ceremony and the wedding, which is a bridersquos reception hosted by the bridersquos family.Some of the wedding venues decorated by Hassan and his team The final event - which we get to see come to le in the first episode of the three-part series - is the walima, a more relaxed bash hosted by the groomrsquos side.Budgets for Asian weddings can top pound, nowadays, but how did a once relatively modest occasion evolve into the lavish and arguably obscene events we see today Asian weddings have changed very fast and dramatically because of the Internet and social media, Hassan explains, ldquowhich influence a lot of peoplersquos decisions. People pick up dferent ideas from other peoplersquos weddings and events in other parts of the world and then they want that for themselves. Itrsquos an aspiration thing and the Internet has a lot to play, making people more educated, savvy and know what they want. Because of this, people think out the box and are able to put their own personal touch on the wedding to make it unique.Thinking outside the box is definitely what Hassanrsquos clients do well. The biggest wedding he has planned in his career involved a dizzying , guests. With clients more cost-savvy now, he describes how over-the-top ideas from couples are never far.ldquoThe craziest idea wersquove had was when a couple wanted , flowers hung from the ceiling two years ago, Hassan remembers, amused. ldquoIn big spaces like conference rooms, it softens the space, but these things are expensive - particularly with fresh flowers - so we then have to look at the next best thing, how we can achieve it, how it can be set up. We would then have to work with other professionals who can work at heights.In the first episode, we get to see a wedding being put together in the cityrsquos Crowne Plaza as Hassan and his staff scramble to hang hundreds of flowers from the ceiling, albeit fake ones.He explains: ldquoFresh flowers are obscene and not everyone can afford it, so we then look at articial flowers, which look just as real. For the sake of a few hours, they want it to look good, obviously.What is it about weddings that have Asian families going over-the top ldquoPakistanis are not that extravagant in their day-to-day lives, but a wedding is when theyrsquoll either be welcoming a new addition to the family or giving their daughter away, so theyrsquoll spend the most, says Hassan.ldquoWith pound, budgets, you have to take everything into consideration, including clothes and jewellery, which are a big expense. Clients travel to Pakistan and India to get their shopping done. Remember, Asian weddings can last for days as well. Some families will put marquees up at home and host pre-wedding events where the whole family comes together. It does add up to quite a lot of money, but the Bank of Mum and Dad can help out. Though, these days, professional couples themselves are very much in control and can pay everything themselves. Many live with their parents so they have that additional income saved up, he adds.Viewers will get to see a Falkirk mum planning a joint walima for her two sons in episode one as Hassanrsquos clients work on ways to cut down costs.Hassan says: ldquoSome will realise itrsquos too extravagant and theyrsquoll decide to put money into a house instead. But, nowadays, clients will cut down on the number of events they have and just roll it all into one day to cut down on costs.Working with demanding clients and large families comes with its tribulations. Hassan says: ldquoWhen yoursquore working with two families trying to create one event, sometimes it gels really well and other times itrsquos the opposite and you get friction. Usually, one family will sit back and let the other take control. If both families have dferent views, they can clash. Irsquove had that before and it does get tricky. Wersquove witnessed barnies happening right in front of us and it can get awkward, but itrsquos just about stepping in and mediating. In the end, theyrsquore always smiling.Itrsquos been his busiest year on record and, as Asian weddings continue to evolve, whatrsquos next for Hassan and his team ldquoWersquore seeing people sht away from having weddings in Scotland and opting for destination weddings. Several clients have gone out to Turkey, Dubai, South of France and Italy. Thatrsquos a new, up-and-coming trend, to take all the guests out on a holiday and have all your events out there. The weather has a big part to play as well. Wersquore working on some at the moment.What are Hassanrsquos hopes for another series  ldquoWersquoll see from the feedback and what everyonersquos got to say after the third episode airs and then wersquoll take it from there.Catch ldquoGetting Hitched Asian Style on BBC Scotland at pm on Thursday, March .For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages

title: Iain Macwhirter  28 days to go and Westminster won   t even reject no deal  let alone back a People   s Vote
story: I could give you a pious expression of naive hope. Tell you that therersquos going to be a referendum on Brexit, that the ERG are back in their box, Jezza has finally come good, and Theresa May has been put in a secure unit. But I canrsquot in all honesty agree with commentators, like the blessed Polly Toynbee, who believe we are now on the road to redemption.Yes, Labour did repeat its promise to hold a referendumJeremy Corbynrsquos ldquoworkable plan of a permanent customs union is rejected ndash as it was in one of last weekrsquos many meaningless votes. Oh, and Labour will support a referendumthere is no General Election. Anda no deal Tory deal looks likely. If, , .ButLabour really wanted to eliminate the threat of no deal, it would have moved heaven and earth to deliver the SNPrsquos motion calling for precisely that.Looking back on this dismal week, the standout, surely, is the arrant insanity of Parliament ndash a rational body of elected representatives ndash failing to take the opportunity to rule out an event which would put the army on the streets, interrupt food and medicine supplies, and cause the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.Yes, the Yvette Cooper Oliver Letwin amendmentwas endorsed by Parliament overwhelmingly, after Theresa May gave it the nod. This means that there will be an extension to Article Parliament doesnrsquot support a deal by March . Well and good. If therersquos one thing the UK Parliament is supremely good at itrsquos failing to agree.It doesnrsquot like Mayrsquos botched deal, the Norway option, EFTA or any other solution that Brussels thinks acceptable. So that means an extension is inevitable. Except that the French president Emmanuel Macron and the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, have made clear that the  countries of the EU , will only contemplate delaying Britainrsquos departure from the EUit is for ldquoa purpose. Holding more meaningless votes, staging more ministerial resignations and arguing on College Green outside Parliament do not, one suspects, constitute a legitimate purpose.Still, everyone seems convinced that an extension is in the bag. This led to largely unwarranted excitement on the Remain side. With Labour calling for a Peoplersquos Voteand Theresa Mayrsquos deadline finally breached, Twitter went into orbit. Lord Adonis all but declared victory in the Battle of Brexit. Europhiles were dancing in the streets, metaphorically at least, and jeering at the nasty Brexiters who had been defeated by the forces of good. It was like the last reel of Lord of the Rings.But such triumphalism was premature. Much as I wish it were the case, there is still no majority in Parliament for a referendum. Stephen K Bush, the political editor of the New Statesman, has been counting them out and counting them back in again and he is adamant that the Labour Brexit rebels will prevent any motion for a referendum passing through Parliament. He says at least  Labour MPs are opposed. Hersquos right.ldquoRebels here is something of a misnomer since there is widespread belief that Brexit is the outcome desired by their leader. Indeed, on one interpretation of last weekrsquos events, Jeremy Corbyn has managed to find a way to secure Brexit while also appearing to support a referendum. This is because what is called the Kyle Wilson amendment.This cross-party proposal, which Labour is minded to support on March , calls for MPs to agree to Theresa Mayrsquos deal , but only on the condition that there is a referendum to validate it. Bingo. Labour can tell all its working-class Brexit supporters in target marginals that, yes, it didnrsquot block Brexit. But Jeremy can also curry favour with the Remainiacs of Islington by appearing to support a Peoplersquos Vote.Itrsquos very clever, but to my mind somewhat bonkers. Why would Labour help pass Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which Jeremy Corbyn has said is worse than no deal, would lose thousands of jobs and would lock the UK into a backstop from which it cannot escape  At least this is what he has said repeatedly in the Commons.Surely, a vote is a vote. Theresa May could legitimately say that her deal has been endorsed by Parliament, and call on Labour to campaign for it in any referendum. Not that she has the slightest intention of calling a referendum.Theresa Mayrsquos strategy is the same as it ever was: not listening, nothing has changed, take it or leave it. It pains me to say it, but the Prime Minister at least has a strategy. It is to run down the clock, while allowing the ious tribes in Parliament and in her Cabinet, to fall out among themselves.Itrsquos working. Labour is moving ever more in the direction of her deal, however much they may deny it. Parliament canrsquot agree on anything.There are tears in Cabinet and more resignations ndash  from the Government so far. But whorsquos counting  The European Research Group ndash that comically misnamed faction of extreme Brexiters ndash has reportedly split over William Rees-Moggrsquos equivocation on the Irish backstop.And while all about is chaos and acrimony, so ticks away the clock until Brexit day. Twenty-eight days at the time of writing. Goodness me, is that really the time  Yes it is. As in the film of the same name, the zombies are stirring.I accept that is an offensive way to describe Nigel Faragersquos ldquoBrexit Betrayal march from Sunderland to London. But it could get nasty on the road.What do I think will happen in the end  As Irsquove been saying in this column since Christmas, I think Parliament will block a no-deal Brexit. There will be an extension of Article , and Labour will probably end up backing Mayrsquos deal, or abstaining on it which amounts to the same thing.If Labour, by some remote chance, continues to reject Mayrsquos deal or its iants, in the meaningful vote on the inglorious twelfth, then I think MPs would still reject a referendum. There is still no majority for one, and Labourrsquos die-hard Brexiters are not for turning.Which makes the most likely option ndash about the only one Theresa May can authorise as PM under her prerogative powers ndash would be to revoke Article . Pull the plug. End it.OK, so thatrsquos wishful thinking on my part. Her Government would fall and precipitate an election. But looking at the chaos that is Brexit, and the lack of time, it seems as good a shout as any, especiallyBrussels reject a meaningless extension.If Britain canrsquot decide how to leave the EU, an extension to Article  would be pointless. The sensible thing to do would be to cancel Brexit, go away, and think again.

title: herald-diary-so-thats-what-tutti-frutti-is-about
story: THE news story in The Herald about a drunk having to call the police after falling asleep in a Greenock pub toilet and being locked in, reminded George Dale in Beith: "When I was  I attended a stag night and we ended up in a Chinese restaurant near Charing Cross. I went to the toilet and I, too, fell asleep on the throne. On awakening a long time later I started to vacate the facility and could not understand why one leg was lower and wetter than the other as I progressed out to a locked, dark restaurant."A startled staff member, sleeping on a row of chairs, jumped up, frightened me near to death and let me out. The reason for the odd walking experience was the floor level urinal trough."MajesticGREAT to see John Byrnes classic series Tutti Frutti, about The Majestics band, on the new BBC Scotland channel. We remember when National Theatre of Scotland director Vicky Featherstone adapted it for the theatre and she gushed in The Stage magazine: "To me the Majestics are representative of a certain kind of working-class Scottish male, and the question is whether or not theyre going to be able to reinvent themselves into a new kind of male in the s."When The Stage asked writer John Byrne what he thought of Vickys adaptation he replied: "I was delighted and surprised ndash especially when she told me what it was really about. I had no idea."Switched onON the topic of TV licences, Neil Shepherd in Orkney tells us: "While a student in Aberdeen halls, a friend received a warning phone call from the downstairs neighbour that the inspector was on his way up. The TV was quickly hidden in a cupboard and the inspector was shown around a room where all the furniture was facing an empty table in the corner with a TV-shaped square surrounded by dust.He nodded then moved onto the next flat."Hard to swallowPARENTING, continued. Says a Hyndland reader: "My daughter offered me a bit of her chocolate bar. I was surprised as shes not much of a sharer. Just as I was chewing away her brother came storming in demanding to know where his chocolate bar was, and giving me a hurtful look when he saw me chewing.His sister will go far."Name callingAH, the minefield of married le. A Lanarkshire reader is still shaking his head over a recent conversation with his better half which went: "Whats the name of, what do you call him, his brother "His response: "Who " brought the reply: "You know, thingummy!" And thus the conversation ended, with him none the wiser.What a knightSTORIES about how pupils address their teachers reminded Barham Brummage: "I was in a music lesson where the teacher was a fairly intimidating chap. As he read out the register one young lad was left out and he put up a tentative hand. Whats your name, son  enquired the teacher.Desiring to show due respect, the boy blurted out, Sir, Angus. Needless to say we all, including the music teacher, referred to him thereafter as Sir Angus."X marks spotWE asked about sneaking into adult films when young and Derek Miller in Torrance recalls: "As teenagers in East Kilbride in the early s, a group of us got excited with an afternoon showing of a sleazy lsquoadultrsquo double bill at a town centre cinema so we duly dogged off school and went along."When the lights went up, I turned around sheepishly to be greeted by leering grins from half the senior male intake of our school. Thankfully, there were no teachers in attendance."Drink to thatWE mentioned Wetherspoonsrsquo boss Tim Martin being keen on Brexit and a Glasgow reader says: ldquoSurely the reason he is so keen on Brexit is that, as a multiple pub owner, he knows full well that the entire population will either be celebrating or drowning their sorrows after Brexit in his pubs "

title: luxury-hotel-rises-from-a-historic-gap-site-in-edinburgh
story: But now the curtain has finally been drawn back on the new pound million hotels which has risen from Edinburghrsquos Old Town.Standing eight storeys tall above the Unesco World Heritage site, the sandstone-clad Market Street Hotel has already drawn plaudits from architects and is now accepting bookings.The -room building was built on an empty ldquogap which had seen a number of failed attempts at development and has been selected as the first member of the Design Hotels organisation in Scotland ndash a global body which recognises hotels built with cutting-edge design and architecture.The hotel was designed by JM Architects, with interiors by FG Stijl. It is part of the Carlton Hotel Group and isdue to open in May, with bookings available from mid-June. Prices will start from pound per night.:Edinburgh thrives as it defies fallout from financial crisisA nod has been given to Auld Reekiersquos heritage, with the buildingrsquos champagne lounge, The Norrsquo Loft, taking its name from the Nor Loch, which occupied the space where Princes Street Gardens can now be found, between the th and th centuries.General manager Jill Darling said: ldquoWersquore proud to call Edinburgh our home and to sit in such an enviable spot at the heart of this great city.ldquoWe donrsquot just want our guests to experience our hotel, our location means they can explore all that the capital has to offer, from its rich history and culture to its sparkling restaurant and bar scene.Market Street is the latest in a number of multi-million-pound developments taking place in the city, with fresh le being breathed into the now-demolished St James Quarter on the other side of Waverley Station.: Ribbon hotel dubbed dog dirtHere, an poundm development is due to be completed by , comprising , sq ft of retail space, anchored by a John Lewis store.It will also feature a multi-screen cinema, a -room hotel and  private apartments.The firm behind the scheme, TH Real Estate, bills the work as one of the largest and most signicant regeneration projects underway in the UK, and claims to have invested almost poundm in locally sourced building materials and workforce.Up to , construction jobs are being created during the building of the new quarter. In the longer term, the development is expected to create more than , permanent full-time jobs in a iety of sectors.A total of , tonnes of material from demolition ndash the equivalent of , small cars or  blue whales ndash has been recycled and reused onsite for building purposes.More than , people have been or still are working on the site,  per cent of them living within  miles of the project.And nearly  daysrsquo work experience has been provided for local schools, universities and graduates.However, there has been controversy over one of the proposed buildings.Developers have been given the go-ahead to build a tall tower-style hotel clad in a spiralling strip of bronze-coloured stainless steel.: Pictures - Demolition of Edinburghs most unloved landmarkDubbed the Ribbon Hotel, the building has ided opinion, with some likening it to a walnut whip, others saying it looks more like a ldquodog t***.Market Street Hotel is hoping its own design is more favourable with locals. Ms Darling added: ldquoWersquore creating a space with a truly unique, vibrant and infectious energy and wersquore thrilled to now offering city dwellers and urban explorers the chance to be among the first to stay with us.

story: An international investigation has exposed how the network received money from companies linked to major fraud, and was managed by the Russian bank Troika Dialog.The philanthropist and oligarch, Ruben Vardanyan, is the bankrsquos former boss.The web of more than  offshore companies is exposed in a leak of . million confidential bank transactions to the Organised Crime and Corruption Reporting Project , a consortium of east European investigative journalists who shared information and documents with the BBC and the .Between  and  the Princersquos Charities Foundation received three payments, adding up to , via a now-defunct bank in Lithuania.The leaked bank data shows the last of the payments went to an account held by the Princersquos Charities Foundation.There is no suggestion that Mr Vardanyan was himself involved in any criminal activity.His lawyers told the BBC he was not involved in the operations, managementor activities of the wealth management arm of Troika Dialog Group, and that he hadalways acted in a transparent way.A spokesman for The Prince of Walesrsquo Charitable Foundation and The Dumfries House Trust said: ldquoThe charities apply robust due diligence processes. title: margaret-taylor-from-laura-to-louella-why-are-men-valued-more-highly-than-women
story: Coming two years after she achieved the exact same result in Belgrade and a year after she took ,m gold at both the European Championships and the Diamond League, Ms Muir is, in the words of her coach Andy Young, fast becoming ldquoa world star of sport, never mind athletics. Indeed, hers was and is a truly landmark achievement from a young Scottish athlete.Not that yoursquod have known ityou rely on newspaper front pages to tell you whatrsquos important. Because far from the image of this remarkable woman achieving this remarkable milestone dominating the main picture slots, just two daily papers thought her triumph worthy of such note. Just imagineit was a male athlete that had done the double-double so soon after clinching two other golds and think about how that achievement would have been framed. Yep, thatrsquos right, it would have been plastered everywhere.Read more:How s sexism refuses to die out in workplaces of If sport in general or athletics in particular arenrsquot really your thing you might not think this matters. But failing to recognise from a woman an achievement that would have been lauded had it been notched up by a man only serves to reinforce the prevailing assumption that women are somehow worth less and so should be valued less highly than men. That can have devastating consequences.Louella Fletcher-Michie was a young woman whose le was deemed to be of less value than a manrsquos, with the man who deemed it so allowing her to die as a result. Having gone to a music festival to celebrate her thbirthday, Ms Fletcher-Michie - whose father is Scottish actor John Michie - died an hour before what should have been a happy day thanks to her boyfriend filming her suffering the ill effects of a drugs binge he had administered rather than calling for help.Though experts testied that medical intervention would have given the young woman a  per cent chance of survival, the court heard that Ceon Broughton had been more concerned with activating his own suspended sentence for kne possession than his girlfriendrsquos welfare, the cruellest of cruel ironies being that he ended up with a prison sentence anyway as a result.But while Ceon Broughton did a terrible thing, can he really be blamed for thinking his le and his future were worth more than his girlfriendrsquos when that is the narrative that will have been reinforced through his entire le Read more:Revealed: "Appalling" scale of sexual harassment in Scotlands workplacesYou see it in schools, where the hard death of old gender stereotypes pushes girls towards lsquofemininersquo subjects and boys towards career-enhancing ones, and in workplaces, where male labour is still regularly remunerated more highly than female despite that being outlawed half a century ago. You see it in sport, where in spite of great strides being made menrsquos tournaments continue to be seen as weightier than womenrsquos, and - perhaps most explicitly - in politics, where womenrsquos reputations can be sullied in a moment, sacriced at the altar of a power struggle between supposedly great men.Indeed, as the recently screened television series The Clinton Affair laid bare, not a single man who got together to try to overthrow then US President Bill Clinton in the s gave a damn about the effect their plot would have on anyone , with the ruin of his paramour Monica Lewinsky seen as nothing more than a simple by-product of their only aim: to bring down the government of a man whose politics they despised. How they - and Mr Clinton, who wasted no time in throwing Ms Lewinsky to the wolves in a bid to save his own skin - must have rubbed their hands with glee when the rabidly misogynistic press set about rubbishing her reputation on their behalf.Buteven the most powerful man on earth - who is, after all, the male role model par excellence - is fully bought into the narrative that men are important and women are expendable, why would someone like Ceon Broughton think any dferently  Men, these stories tell us, are what matter, and a media that is still largely controlled by men - who place stories and choose pictures according to what they believe should be of interest - routinely backs that assumption up.It doesnrsquot have to be this way. Last year Monika Lewinsky wrote an article for Vanity Fair in which she explained why,  years after the relationship that ruined her reputation had ended, she chose to talk to the makers of The Clinton Affair. Recalling how Bill Clinton had once said that he, as President of the United States, had entered into an inappropriate relationship with an intern ldquobecause I could, she said: ldquoWhy did I choose to participate in this docuseries  One main reason: because I could.Newspaper editors could,they wanted to, start properly telling womenrsquos stories too. They would find no shortage of material and the impact would be immense.

title: scottish-and-welsh-parliaments-to-vote-on-brexit-opposition
story: Both motions object to the deal to leave the European Union by the UK Government and declare that a no-deal Brexit would be "completely unacceptable".If passed, they would call for the UK Government to "take immediate steps to prevent the UK leaving the EU without a deal" as well as an extension of Article .:Brexit: Shoppers claim to have started stockpiling food for no-dealScotlands Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell said: "This is an unprecedented event: the first time in  years of devolution that the Scottish Parliament and National Assembly for Wales have debated the same motion simultaneously."We are taking this historic step to send a strong message to the UK Government that it must stop pursuing such a disastrous course of action."The Prime Ministers deal will cause major, lasting damage to jobs, living standards and public services such as the NHS, and should be voted down."The UK Government must also stop using the threat of a catastrophic no-deal outcome to blackmail the UK Parliament into accepting her deeply damaging plans."An extension that stops the clock on Brexit would allow time for agreement to be reached on a better way forward, which the Scottish Government believes should be a second EU referendum with Remain on the ballot paper."A UK Government spokeswoman said: "An orderly Brexit is in the UKs best interests and the best way to achieve that is for MPs of all parties to support the Prime Ministers deal."The deal is a good one for Scotland, Wales and the whole of the UK - it delivers the result of the referendum, gives us a close future partnership with the EU, and guarantees citizens rights.:Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard has failed us, GMB leader says"Refusing to support the Prime Ministers deal simply makes a damaging no-deal more likely."Scottish Conservative interim leader Jackson Carlaw MSP added: "At a time when most people want to see parties compromising in order to deliver an orderly Brexit, the SNP is still engaged in game-playing and stunts."This debate has little to do with moving Scotland and the UK forward and everything to do with Nicola Sturgeon using Brexit to push for independence. That is her only Brexit priority."Labour - in Wales and Scotland - should know better than to play along."The vote is expected to take place at pm in Edinburgh and Cardf.

story: The NASUWT, which has , members, is to issue a formal trade dispute with the Scottish Government over the latest offer.The ballot will also cover concerns over workload, pupil indiscipline and bullying of staff.The move comes as the Educational Institute of Scotland, the countrys largest teaching union, presses ahead with its strike ballot.The NASUWT, which said its ballot would open on th March, has also written to the John Swinney, the Education Secretary, lodging the formal trade dispute with the Government.Read more: EIS presses ahead with strike ballotChris Keates, NASUWT general secretary, said: "Feedback from our members has demonstrated that they are angry about the year-on-year cuts they have suffered to their pay."They have also said they are equally and, in some cases, even more angry about the failure of Government and employers to tackle excessive workload, growing pupil indiscipline and other adverse practices, including the culture developing in too many workplaces of bullying of staff.ldquoIn the light of this and having failed to reach agreement in the current pay talks, we have decided that simply to have a trade dispute and ballot over pay would mean that other issues of deep concern were not being addressed."Our trade dispute with Government and employers will now, therefore, cover all of these issues of concern."Read more: Scottish secondary teachers back pay dealEarlier this week, theEIS formally rejected an offer of a series of risesworth  per cent April plus another  per cent year.In recognition of concern over problems in the recruitment and retention of teachers, councils hadalso agreed to back a restructuring of wider pay scales and look at pay for promoted teachers.However, teaching unions have been campaigningfor an immediate  per cent rise for all staff arguing salaries have fallen behind over the past decade.More than  per cent of EIS members voted to back the deal, but  per cent rejected it.

title: nicola-sturgeon-snp-wants-to-make-scotland-the-best-country-in-which-to-live-and-work
story: Last week marked a number of important milestones towards Scotland becoming a fairer country ndash which is a key objective of the SNP Scottish Government.:Hiring declines at its fastest pace in seven years as Brexit concerns continueOne of those milestones was the publication of our Fair Work Action Plan.The SNP wants to make Scotland be the best country in which to live, work, invest and do business. At the heart of this ambition lies our commitment to fair work.For employees fair work means decent wages, secure contracts and just working practices. Fair work is not only right in principle, it also results in better health and greater wellbeing for workers. In turn this drives creativity, innovation and productivity. It also reduces staff turnover, which means increased profitability for businesses.With employment reserved to Westminster, Scotland does not yet have the powers to make fair work a legal requirement, but that doesnrsquot stop us from taking as much action as we can to encourage fair work practices.For years the Scottish Government has championed good employment practices through schemes such as the Scottish Business Pledge and Living Wage accreditation, and we are now strides ahead of the rest of the UK in many areas.There are now , accredited Living Wage Employers in Scotland. We also have a higher proportion of employees paid at least the real living wage than any other UK nation. We have gone further than any other part of the UK to help eradicate blacklisting from public contracts, and we have ensured that no person directly employed by the Scottish Government is on an exploitative zero hours contract.:Scottish and Welsh parliaments to vote on Brexit oppositionItrsquos great progress and we want to do even more to support workers and businesses across the country, which is why we have been working with the Fair Work Convention and the Scottish Trades Union Congress on the Fair Work Action Plan.The plan sets out a range of new measures to embed good practice, with tailored approaches to meet the needs of inidual businesses.It includes setting up a new Fair Work service for small and micro employers, a new target of increasing the number of employees paid the real living wage by , over the next three years, a revamp of the Scottish Business Pledge to fully align it with fair work practices, and a learning network to better support businesses who want to sign up and meet these objectives.Wersquore working hand in hand with unions and employers to put fair work first in a truly meaningful way. This is an approach that is good for workers, good for businesses and good for Scotland as a whole, and that is why wersquore so determined to lead by example.Ultimately, for as long as employment law is reserved to Westminster the Scottish Governmentrsquos ability to eradicate unfair working practices will be limited, but that wonrsquot stop us acting where we can.Another area which remains substantially reserved to Westminster, but where some new powers are nevertheless allowing us to take a dramatically dferent approach to the rest of the UK is social security.:Scotland best part of UK for workplace gender ersitySince the Social Security Act was passed by the Scottish Parliament last year, we have been able to improve the lives of thousands of people across the whole of Scotland.We have delivered the Carersrsquo Allowance Supplement, paying out more than pound million to over , carers. Wersquove also put pound. million into the pockets of more than , families in Scotland through the new Best Start Grant. In fact since our new agency, Social Security Scotland first opened its doors, we have paid out an additional pound million to people across the country. That is already making a real dference - but there is so much more to come.This year there will be four new benefits to help carers and low-income families, and we have now announced that we will take responsibility for the rest of the devolved benefits from next April. From there we will roll out disability and carers benefits, and winter weather payments.Having these powers is good for the Scottish Parliament but it will be truly transformational for the people in Scotland who for too long have felt the failures of the UK Governmentrsquos callous approach to benefits.And having these powers means that we are able to build a dignied, respectful social security system, with benefits co-designed with the people of Scotland.These powers have broken new ground and by the end of the process ndash which takes time because of the complexities involved and the need to get it right ndash we will have accomplished the most complicated extension of devolution since the Parliament was reconvened  years ago.It shows how Scotland can choose a dferent path and create a more equal and prosperous country, with fairness at its core.Imagine what more we could dowe held the full range of powers of independent Parliaments.This article originally appeared in The Evening Times

title: snp-economic-plan-would-torpedo-indyref2-alliance
story: Colin Fox, co-convener of the Scottish Socialist Party and a former board member of the last Yes campaign, said the Growth Commission would ldquotorpedo another -style alliance.He said it reminded him of ldquosomething New Labour could have produced, adding: ldquoI sat on the Yes Scotland Advisory Board and played a constructive, collegiate role. But we will be unable to do so againthe Growth Commission plan is put at the heart of Yes.The Scottish Greens also said the SNP would be "well advised" not to followthe plans.The attack comes a day after influential members of the SNP warned making the Commissionrsquos ideas into party policy could cause a ldquocrisis in the independence movement.:Row over SNPs currency plans for an independent ScotlandChaired by former MSP turned corporate lobbyist Andrew Wilson, the Commissionrsquos blueprint for independence has been severely criticised on the Left of the movement.It recommended halving the deficit, reining in public spending and keeping the pound for the first decade or after independence to establish market credibility.The respected Institute of Fiscal Studies said this would be akin to keeping Tory austerity.Now Finance Secretary Derek Mackay and depute leader Keith Brown have tabled a motion for next monthrsquos SNP conference in Edinburgh accepting the Commissionrsquos proposals.Although there is an ostensible commitment to creating a new Scottish currency, this would be subject to six annually-assessed economic tests set down by the Commission, which some SNP activists believe are so vague they may never be met.Mr Mackay admitted on Sunday that an accelerated currency plan would depend on an economic boom after independence.:SNP currency plan based on economic boom after Yes vote branded fantasyMr Fox, who sat on Yes Scotland before the  vote, said the Commissionrsquos ideas meant cuts to public spending, privatisation, further austerity and the continued use of sterling.He said: ldquoThe wider Yes movement will simply not rally behind this recommendation.ldquoThe Scottish Socialist Party will certainly not participate in a Yes campaign based around this free market, right of centre economic prospectus.ldquoRather we will work with others to put the case for Independence as meaning profound change, environmental sustainability and social justice for all in our new nation.: Letters:Plans for a Scottish currency are doomed to failHe went on: ldquoWilson offers no material improvement to the often desperate circumstances facing Scotlands working class majority. Yet they are the strongest supporters of Independence precisely because they see progress coming from that route alone.ldquoWilson clearly believes Scotlands working class are already in the bag as far as Independence is concerned and concludes the SNP must therefore appeal above all to middle-class, Middle Scotland. His fiscally conservative economics are therefore designed to appeal to Murrayfield and Milngavie, not Motherwell or Methil."Pandering to a wealthy elite not only risks losing the % support we won in , it makes the task of winning over Scotlandrsquos working class majority impossible.ldquoAnd without them Yes cannot triumph.Green MSP Patrick Harvie, who also served on Yes Scotland, said: "The SNPrsquos Growth Commission has been widely criticised, and the wider campaign for independence would be well advised not to base an economic plan on this isive report.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins added: "The SNPrsquos Growth Commission clearly outlines the years of public spending cuts and massive tax increases that would be necessary in an independent Scotland.Perhaps the Scottish Socialists should rethink their outdated ideology."LibDem spokesperson Wendy Chamberlain said: ldquoThe SNP are repelling independence foot soldiers with moves to endorse their home-made austerity plans.ldquoThe Growth Commission sets out how an independent Scotland would have no choice but to make harsh cuts to public services in order to bring down the deficit. The Scottish Liberal Democrats will oppose these chaotic plans to make our country and people poorer.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said:ldquoThe campaign to leave the UK is tearing itself apart because there simply isnrsquot a positive economic case for Scottish independence.Whether itrsquos the SNP, Green or Socialist Party blueprint, families in Scotland would face deeper austerity and steeper tax rises.For the SNP, Mr Brown said: ldquoThe proposals I have put forward to conference will enable us to build a solid and persuasive  for independence.ldquoThey give us the powers to fulfil our potential ndash to build a fairer society, based on shared values of equality and compassion.ldquoWe can reject austerity outright, and protect valued public services like our NHS from the harm of Tory cuts and the damage of Brexit.ldquoWe can pursue a currency policy thatrsquos right for Scotland to maximise our opportunities as a proud, successful European nation in a global economy.ldquoWe can raise our sights by building an independent Scotland that brings about the change we need to face the challenges of tomorrow.

title: nicola-sturgeon-theresa-mays-only-consistency-on-brexit-has-been-her-contempt-for-scotland
story: The First Minister said that the Prime Minister should stop "pretending that changes to the backstop are possible despite all of the evidence to the contrary" and she should accept that her plan is a "thoroughly bad deal" which would be a "long term social and economic disaster"She called for the rejection of Theresa Mays deal in favour of a second vote on the EU referendum stating that "The Scottish Government has made clear that we see continued EU membership as the best outcome for Scotland and the UK."Andit canrsquot be secured for the UK as a whole, we believe that option should be open to Scotland as an independent country."She opened the debate by emphasising that it was the first time that both the Scottish Parliament and Welsh Assembly have opened debates at the same time on the same motion. She said that the Welsh and Scottish Government had"been brought together by our dismay ndash bordering now on despair ndash at the UK Governmentrsquos approach to Brexit.":Nicola Sturgeon: SNP wants to make Scotland the best country in which to live and work inIn an address to the chamber, she said:"As recently as last summer, the Prime Minister confidently told me that by the autumn of last year, not only would we know the terms of exit, we would also know signicant detail about the UKrsquos future relationship with the EU."And yet here we are, just  days until the UK is due to leave the EU. And still we donrsquot knowthere will be any agreed terms of exit. We donrsquot knowthere will be a transition phase."FM: "A second referendum provides everyone with a second chance. While Scotland, of course, has the option of independence, for the UK as a whole, another referendum is now the best of the options available.""And the terms of the future relationship are not much more than a blank sheet of paper. The potential consequences for businesses, communities, iniduals and public services growmore stark by the day."In the face of all this chaos, the Prime Minister is showing no decisive leadership. Instead of doing the right thing and ruling out a no deal exit at any stage, she insists on freewheeling the car ever closer to the clf edge."She is trying to run down the clock, making undeliverable promises to hardline Brexiteers and offering tawdry, half baked bribes to Labour MPs.""Her one note of consistency in all of this has been contempt for Scotland. Seemingly, we arenrsquot even worthy of her bribes - though I think we should take that as a compliment.:SNP economic plan would torpedo Indyref alliance"The domestic and international standing of the Westminster system of government has surely never been lower in any of our letimes. This fiasco should not be allowed to continue for even one day more. The Scottish and Welsh Parliaments are today making three demands."The first is that the prospect of leaving the EU with no deal is ruled out - not just at the end of March, but at any time."The First Minister also called for an extension to Article , insisting that the Scottish Government was doing everything it could to prevent Brexit and prepare for a no-deal exit.First Minister @nicolasturgeon is addressing @ScotParl to open the debate on a historic joint motion with @AssemblyWales against the damaging @GOVUK #Brexit Withdrawal Agreement. pic lADbBScBMdNicola Sturgeon said: "The third is that an extension of Article  is essential and urgent, and must be requested now. The demand to rule out a ldquono-deal scenario is, I hope, supported across this chamber."The Scottish Government is doing everything we can to plan for and mitigate the impact of a no-deal Brexit.The UK Governmentrsquos own forecasts predict that a no-deal scenario could reduce GDP by % over a  year period. But you just need to look at the nature of the preparations to know that the impact would be much more immediate."She also hit out at the "unforgivably reckless" approach of the UK Government saying:"The UK government has been buying fridges to stockpile medicine. It has been testing motorways and airfields in Kent for use as lorry parks. It has been awarding and then cancelling ferry contracts to businesses which donrsquot even have ships.:Hiring declines at its fastest pace in seven years as Brexit concerns continue"It has been taking steps which should be inconceivable in a developed economy in peacetime. And all of it to plan for an avoidable outcome which,it happens, will be by choice."She called for the threat of a No-deal Brexit to be withdrawn stating that "the response to the rejection of Theresa Mayrsquos deal has so far been characterised by delays, denials, dishonesty and most recently desperate attempts at bribery."Urging ministers to reject the Prime Ministers deal, she said that the deal from Theresa May "provides no clarity whatsoever on what our long-term future relationship with the EU looks like. The UK Parliament is effectively being asked to approve a ldquoblindfold Brexit."In short, the deal on the table guarantees more years of uncertainty during which Scotlandrsquos interests will be at the mercy of a vicious, and seemingly never-ending, Tory civil war ndash one where the extreme Brexiteers are currently in the ascendancy."Part and parcel of the approach taken in the PMrsquos deal is the end of freedom of movement. Combined with the despicable hostile migration policy, that could lead to a fall in the number of people working in Scotland and paying tax here.FM: "Andit canrsquot be secured for the UK as a whole, we believe that option should be open to Scotland as an independent country.""The NHS and social care will pay a particularly heavy priceEU nationals are deterred from working here."It could open up our markets to US products which, for very good reasons, are currently banned. And it will damage our economy, our living standards and our NHS.For all these reasons, and more, it must be rejected."Concluding her speech she called for a second referendum stating that Scotland had made it clear that it wished to remain in the EU "The Scottish Government has made clear that we see continued EU membership as the best outcome for Scotland and the UK."Andit canrsquot be secured for the UK as a whole, we believe that option should be open to Scotland as an independent country."The UK Government has ignored us at all stages.""We need an extension long enough to enable a better path to be taken. This could open the way again to the possibility of a single market and customs union compromise."However the preferable alternative option, in my view, is now a second EU referendum. There is a strong democratic case for it."But simply pressing ahead with Brexit - knowing that we are heading for disaster - makes no sense. After all, whatever most people voted for, it clearly wasnrsquot where we are now."A second referendum provides everyone with a second chance. While Scotland, of course, has the option of independence, for the UK as a whole, another referendum is now the best of the options available."

title: uk-government-getting-positive-signals-from-europe-on-brexit-talks
story: "I think the signals we are getting are reasonably positive. I dont want to overstate them because I still think theres a lot of work to do, but I think they do understand that we are being sincere," he told BBC Radio s Today programme.Jeremy Hunt said that although the UK would find a way to prosper in a no-deal scenario"I think that they are beginning to realise that we can get a majority in Parliament because they are seeing the signals coming from the people who voted against the deal before who are saying, crucially, that they are prepared to be reasonable about how we get to that position that we cant legally be trapped in the backstop.":SNP economic plan would torpedo Indyref allianceMr Hunt said that although the UK would "find a way to prosper" in a no-deal scenario, it would cause "huge disruption", adding: "I dont think anyone in the Cabinet wants no deal."Leave-backing former minister Suella Braverman said that a no-deal Brexit would not be "Armageddon" and the UK could be "good to go" for withdrawal on World Trade Organisation terms this month.Ms Braverman, who quit as Brexit minister in November in protest at Theresa Mays deal, said she would not vote for an extension of the Article  process to delay withdrawal beyond March no deal is in place.:Nicola Sturgeon - Theresa Mays only consistency on Brexit has been her contempt for Scotland"I dont think we would see the Armageddon thats been predicted," she told Sky News."At Dover, Operation Brock is there to accommodate any potential queues, but it is very possible that they might not even materialise, because of arrangements."At the end of the day, French and German importers will want to get their goods to purchasers in the UK. There may be political postulating but business and jobs will matter more than a speech by Emmanuel Macron."

title: conservatives-suspend-14-members-over-alleged-islamophobia
story: The move comes followingcomments posted in an unofficial lsquoJacob Rees-Mogg Supporters Grouprsquo on Facebook which called on ldquoturfing all Muslims out of public office and ldquogetting rid of all mosques:We need to be honest about the pervasive Islamophobia that plagues our societyThe news comes after a senior Tory peercalled for an independent inquiry into "institutional" Islamophobia in the party.Former minister Baroness Warsi,who was the first Muslim woman to have a seat at the Cabinet table, warned that the partys failure to address the issue within its ranks risked damaging Conservative chances at the next election.She said there was a "deep-rooted problem" in the party and Theresa May had failed to act.Her intervention came after Tory council candidate Peter Lamb quit after coming under fire for social media comments about Islam.Mr Lamb was due to stand in Harlow, Essex, in Mays local elections despite having been disciplined in .In , he tweeted: "Islam like alcoholism [sic]. The first step to recovery is admit you have a problem."Later in the same year, he tweeted: "Turkey buys oil from ISIS. Muslims sticking together.":Protest held in Edinburgh against IslamophobiaHe said: "I deeply regret my remarks on social media. At no point did I intend to cause any offence to the Muslim community. I have reflected on my comments and decided that I should step down as a local election candidate and resignthe Conservative party with immediate effect."A Conservative spokesman said: "Mr. Lamb was investigated and suspended by his local association back in . He has subsequently resigned from the party."Discrimination or abuse of any kind is wrong and will not be tolerated."When CCHQ have been made aware of cases we have acted swtly and decisively, suspending or expelling those involved and launching an immediate investigation under our partys code of conduct."Lady Warsi rejected the claim that the Tories were acting to address the problem.She told BBC Radio s World at One: "We have a deep-rooted problem of anti-Muslim comments, Islamophobic comments, racist comments that have been made right from the top - from MPs through to councillors, council candidates, members, linked groups."She said she had previously suggested an internal inquiry to deal with the issue, but added: "I think it has now gone beyond that and we need an independent inquiry."She went on: "We cannot have a situation where a mainstream political party is sending out a message in the way it is acting that certain parts of our country, certain communities in our country, certain citizens in our country, are simply not welcome in our party and therefore are creating this environment in which, sadly, I think we will feel the impact at the next election."Lady Warsi urged Tory chief executive and treasurer Sir Mick Davis to act, claiming Mrs May and party chairman Brandon Lewis "have failed".

title: record-vacancies-for-consultant-psychiatrists-in-scotland-over-one-in-10-posts-empty
story: Vacancy rates were highest among specialists in old age psychiatry, with almost one in fiveof posts empty at a time when incidence of dementia is soaring.Brian Sloan, Age Scotlandrsquos chief executive, said: ldquoThe rising number of staff vacancies to support people with dementia is sadly not surprising."The social and health care sector in Scotland is under enormous pressure with problems recruiting and retaining staff."However, it means that older people living with dementia are not properly supported through their diagnosis or needs."With the right support people with dementia can live well and independently."More must be done to encourage people to see old age psychiatry care as a fulfilling career and this includes better pay packages.Read more: End inequality of terminally ill dementia patients paying for their care, urges reportOne in  positions for child and adolescent psychiatrists are also vacant amid criticism over y waiting times for young people experiencing mental health crises.The latest figures from ISD Scotland show that more than a quarter of children and teenagers are waiting longer than the  week target for treatment in the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Service , and that nine out of Scotlands  health boards had failed to ensure than % of CAMHS patients were seen on time.NHS Grampian, Borders and Tayside were showing the greatest strain with fewer than half of CAMHS patients getting a first appointment within  weeks. In Grampian, the median wait was  weeks.The data also shows that  out of  young people admitted to hospital for mental health care in   were treated in adult inpatient psychiatric wards due to bed shortages in CAMHS units.Read more: Warning young people becoming extremely ill before they meet criteria for CAMHS treatmentThe Scottish Childrens Services Coalition said the Scottish Government is making "great efforts" to improve mental health provision, including pledging an extra pound million in funds over the next five years, but said the latest figures were "clearly disappointing".A spokesman for the SCSC said: ldquoThere must be a radical transformation of our mental health services, with a focus on preventing such problems arising in the first place and intervening early, especially when we know that half of all mental health problems begin before the age of .In the past five years alone, the total number of consultant psychiatry vacancies in Scotland has spiralled more than threefold, from . to ., based on the whole-time equivalent measure used to adjust for part-time working.As a headcount, the shortfall in psychiatrists has increased from  to , of which  - as of December  - had been empty for six months or more.It is the highest number of vacancies since records began in , and puts the overall vacancy rate for consultant psychiatrists in Scotland at .%.Read more: From overcrowded asylums to a shortage of beds, has psychiatry in NHSScotland come full circle The actual number of staff in post has also dwindled from a peak of . in September , to ., indicating that the increased vacancy rate has been driven in part by consultants leaving the NHS and not just an increase in the number of posts being created.A spokesman for the Royal College of Psychiatrists Scotland said: ldquoWorkforce is one of the biggest challenges facing the mental health sector and this % increase in vacant posts is deeply concerning.ldquoThe Royal College of Psychiatristsrsquo lsquoChoose Psychiatryrsquo campaign is intended to encourage medical students to choose a speciality which is increasingly in demand."The campaign has already produced results across Great Britain, with a % increase in the amount of doctors choosing psychiatry in  compared with .ldquoThe College will be running its next workforce census in  which will provide detailed analysis of the psychiatric workforce in Scotland, England, Northern Ireland and Wales.It comes as BMA Scotland hit out at an ldquoongoing and worrying overall level of consultant vacancies across NHS Scotland.The ISD Scotland figures show that there was a total consultant shortfall of , including  posts not filled after six months.However, the trade union has previously voiced concerns that the true picture is likely to be much worse, as the official statistics do not take into account posts that have not yet been advertised or which are removed after recruitment efforts fail.Dr Simon Barker, chair of BMA Scotlands consultant committee, said: ldquoVacancies ndash and long term vacancies in particular ndash continue to be an ongoing and worrying problem in the NHS."Too many posts are lying empty for far too long, and this is impacting on the care we as doctors are able to provide.ldquoThere are just not enough doctors working in the NHS, which means those in post have to work doubly hard to cover the work of colleagues who simply donrsquot exist.ldquoWhat makes this problem worse is that the figures are still not telling the full story and indeed are hiding the real scale of vacancies among the consultant workforce."Vacant posts are still being left out of these figures for ious reasons. This just isnrsquot acceptable."

title: msps-back-motion-for-uk-to-rule-out-a-no-deal-brexit
story: MSPs have voted to oppose Theresa Mays Brexit deal as well as backing an extension for Article .:Nicola Sturgeon - Theresa Mays only consistency on Brexit has been her contempt for ScotlandMSPs also voted in favour of the UK Government removing the prospect of a no-deal Brexit.The motion from First Minister Nicola Sturgeon branded the prospect of a no-deal Brexit "completely unacceptable" and also urged the UK Government to extend the Article  deadline "so that agreement can be reached on the best way forward to protect the interests of Scotland, Wales and the UK as a whole".Opening the debate earlier today, Nicola Sturgeoncalled for the rejection ofTheresa Mays deal in favour of a second vote on the EU referendum stating that "The Scottish Government has made clear that we see continued EU membership as the best outcome forScotlandand the UK.:UK Government getting positive signals from Europe on Brexit talks"Andit canrsquot be secured for the UK as a whole, we believe that option should be open to Scotland as an independent country."MSPs voted  -  in favour of the motion by the First Minister.An amendment filed by Jackson Carlawslost by  votes to with no abstentions.

title: advice for supporters ahead of scottish cup game at pittodrie
story: Police Scotland officers along with partners are preparing to welcome thousands of football fans to Aberdeen for the Scottish Cup Quarter Final this Sunday.Kick off for the Aberdeen and Rangers game is at .pm and so the City Centre, Pittodrie, Aberdeen Beach and Seaton areas will be busier than usual.Police ask that fans heading to the stadium plan their journeys in advance and allow themselves plenty of extra time to get to the stadium. Match Commander Superintendent Richard Craig is encouraging everyone planning to watch the game either at Pittodrie stadium, a licensed premises or in their home to enjoy the match but to behave responsibly. He said: “It is well-documented that drinking too much alcohol can lead you to become more vulnerable to becoming involved in crime either as a victim or perpetrator. I am urging supporters to behave responsibly and be aware thatyou’re drunk you won’t be allowed entry to the stadium and you’ll miss the match. “Anyone who does become involved in disorder or any act of violence will be dealt with robustly. “Additional officers will be on duty across the North East and within the stadium on Sunday and they will be supported by specialist resources. Our officers are extremely experienced in policing football matches and will be able to offer assistance should anyone need it.“Although the new AWPRis an option for travel we would still advise all football traffic coming from South of Aberdeen to use the traditional supporters’ route into the city .“We are here to ensure the safety and security of all supporters attending the game and minimise disruption to the local community. "I would remind supporters that those entering Pittodrie will be closely monitored for possession of alcohol or pyrotechnics of any kind. It is a condition of entry to the ground that fans allow themselves to be searched and those who refuse will be turned away by the club. “We will be implementing policing operations throughout the day, including spot checks on buses and coaches travelling to the game."Superintendent Craig added: “Pyrotechnics are extremely dangerous and endanger the safety of those around you as well as your own safety. We will take action, you will be arrested.“The match is undoubtedly a big event and we are looking forward to it. title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. title: golden celebrations for couple
story: An Ellon couple have celebrated their golden wedding anniversary, marking  years together.Bill and Isobel Bonner reached the milestone on Friday, March .The couple first met at the Victoria Hall in Ellon, but Bill first dated Isobel’s sister before eventually asking his future we out.Isobel said: “My sister didn’t mind us being together, she ended up being one of my bridesmaids.”The pair were together for three years and engaged for two before marrying at Dyce Parish Church on March   when Isobel was  and Bill was .Bill originally hails from the Tarves area, and Isobel from Oldmeldrum, but the couple made the move to Ellon in January .Through the years Isobel worked at the Stoneywood paper mill before working at Ellon’s former Haldanes store on the checkouts for  years, a job that she really enjoyed.Meanwhile Bill spent time working on a local pig farm and he now works as a lollypop man for Meiklemill School, and is also a part-time janitor.The couple have two sons, Mark and Robbie, and two grandchildren, Ryan and Megan.Bill and Isobel will celebrate their anniversary with close friends and family at the weekend.Commenting on their achievement Isobel said: “It is amazing but the last  years or so have just flown past.“I am the only one in my family to have reached this anniversary.”Bill added that it felt “fantastic” to celebrate  years together.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.thesouthernreporter webimage ..! story: Councillors have approved plans for the erection of a shop on the site of the former IK Motors yard on Inverurie#s Blackhall Industrial Estate.Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee heard on Tuesday that the site, which was formerly used for car sales by IK Motors, is currently unused with all sales now taking place at Highclere Business Park.The new building will be occupied by Screwfix and while the main market served by the company is trade sales, the premises would also be open to members of the public Monday to Friday from am to pm, Saturday from am to pm and Sunday from am to pm.Councillors heard that the proposal would create  jobs.The wider site currently accommodates a number of outlets including the likes of Morrisons, the Strathburn Hotel, Firework Scotland Ltd, Magpie Second Hand Furniture, William Wilson Plumbing Centre andthe Fly Cup Coffee Shop.
