title: Celebration at Dromara for fanciers
story: DROMARA HPS recently held their annual dinner and prize distribution in the Pheasant Restaurant, Annahilt.Unfortunately, numbers were down a little this year with some members unable to attend due to health reasons and the club would like to wish Albert McKinstry and Harry Silcock speedy recoveries.Although some older members were missing, it was great to welcome two new members, Matthew Russell and Christopher Rooney who was accompanied by his we, Gail.After a beautul meal Mr and Mrs Rooney presented the prizes and cups. As everyone knows, Dromara is a strong club but this year surpassed all expectations with the club being the only one in Ireland to have its members win two INFC Nationals.N Black  Son won the Friendship National and N Edgar  Son won the Skibbereen National.The Edgar partnership had a fantastic young bird season as well, winning the NIPA Young Bird National from Rosscarbery.N Black  Son also won the NIPA section D Old Bird Channel fancier. Russell Brothers also had another great season winning the highly prized McBride Cup for the channel averages plus winning Penzance Classic.C  L Fryers had the first bird from Dromara in the Kingrsquos Cup. McKinstry Brothers had some great results along with T Marshall  Son, first bird in Penzance Young Bird, D McCandless Yearling National winner.Mr  Mrs Stevenson again did well inland as well as beating the big boys on the channel by winning first Tallbenny.H Silcock had some great positions and were unlucky to be fourth open Friendship National and still be only second in the club.After the prizes and trophies were handed out Mrs Rooney presented Fiona Stevenson with a bouquet of flowers mdash a small token of thanks for the hospitality from her and Bobby throughout the year.As usual, the highlight of the evening was the ballot and with Stanley McKinstry not attending this year his luck was taken up by Fiona Stevenson.In fact they won so many young birds Bobby thought he might not even have to breed any of his own. N Edgar  Son and N Black  Son kindly donated two young birds each.Edgarrsquos two were won by new member Chris Rooney and Mr  Mrs Stevenson and Blackrsquos two young birds were won by Gordon Kirkpatrick and Mr  Mrs Stevenson.C  l Fryersrsquo young bird was won by non-fancier William Skelly, who is putting it into the stable of N Black  Son to be raced.Cromie  Magee and Sonsrsquo was won by Russell Bros, Mr  Mrs Stevensonrsquos by Chris Rooney, Russell Bros by H Silcock, T Marshall  Sonrsquos by Mr  Mrs Stevenson and A Bradleyrsquos was won by P Connor..prettyPhoto

title: Conal Montgomery samples new sound
story: KILLYLEAGH rocker Conal Montgomery is working on new original music for the first time in years.The well-known singer who has performed at bikersrsquo rallies and conventions around the UK for the last  years may surprise some of his fans with his new sound.Instead of the soaring progressive rock vocals he is known for, Conalrsquos new music is softer, more reflective folk style.The  year-old says that his new music is indicative of where he is in his personal le now.The  year-old explained: ldquoI havenrsquot felt like this for years particularly as when I was drinking I really couldnrsquot be bothered with writing music.ldquoI wrote songs in the early s but alcohol and drugs just took over my le and my time was wasted.ldquoFor  odd years I didnrsquot do anything and now that Irsquom sober, I just have a love for it. I just want to try and put out what Irsquove been feeling for a long time.Conal first developed a love for music by listening to his big brotherrsquos Elvis Presley records.He later began to perform as the lead singer with the local band Bone Idle before moving on to Freak Out and then to Sweet Leaf mdash the band he fronted for  years.ldquoIrsquove been fronting rock bands for the last  years since my early twenties and it was always just covers like AC DC, Led Zeppelin and Lynyrd Skynyrd, Conal continued.ldquoBut when I started to write music, that wasnrsquot what was coming out of me. It was more singer songwriter, folky stuff.ldquoIt wasnrsquot really a surprise to me as the stuff I would have listened to outside my giging would have been the likes of Bob Dylan and Steve Earle.Conal is recording his new songs with the band Stillwater, which also features Killyleagh musician Damien Hanna.While he is experiencing a creative purple patch, the father-of-four does not yet know when the music will be available.ldquoI donrsquot have a title for my new EP yet as Irsquom still writing and Irsquom still recording. I would hope that the EP would be out by the summer and the album by the end of the year but you never know, the EP could turn into the album.He and Stillwater performed two of Conalrsquos new tracks, Venus and All of the People, in an interview on That Like That on NVTV.Conal says that the second track is really resonating with people.ldquoThis track is aimed at society in general, not only young people on Facebook, but all those who point the finger at somebody and gang up on some poor soul, he explained.ldquoThen when something happens to that poor soul, then yoursquoll get the smiley faces and comments of lsquoHe was a great fellarsquo or lsquoShe was a great girlrsquo and hopefully it teaches them a lesson to realise what people might be going through on the inside.Conal is a regular at Denvirrsquos in Downpatrick and will next perform with Stillwater in Portrush Town Hall at the North West  in MayTo watch Conalrsquos interview and performance on NVTVrsquos Talk Like That visit twww.nvtv shows talk-like-that-conal-montgomery Conal and Stillwater on their Facebook pages or ring Conal on  ..prettyPhoto

title: De La Salle head ‘disappointed’ at decision
story: THE principal of De La Salle School in Downpatrick has spoken of his ldquodisappointment in this weekrsquos statement from the Red High Parents and Friends Association.Mr Ciaran Maguire called on all four schools earmarked for the proposed lsquosuper schoolrsquo in Downpatrick ldquoto come together and put their best foot forward.Mr Maguire said he was disappointed for the trustees of De La Salle and St Patrickrsquos, who ldquohave given so much of their lives to the families in East Down.He described their involvement in education has been one of ldquogreat success and achievement.Mr Maguire said De La Salle and St Patrickrsquos were ldquotwo highly effective schools meeting the needs of young men and women in the greater Downpatrick area.He said the trustees had the confidence of staff, pupils and parents at De La Salle and from the wider business community.Mr Maguire remarked: ldquoWithin my last two years as principal of De La Salle, I have witnessed on a daily basis children going to and from St Patrickrsquos, to St Maryrsquos to De La Salle, accessing a curriculum that isnrsquot possible within their own school and sharing both the knowledge and expertise from each of these schools, where the results have been nothing short of excellent for each pupil.ldquoThis collaboration has been up and running successfully for years and is a model of good practice for other post-primary schools to see.ldquoWhat is wrong in having a rsquosuper schoolrsquo  Do the families in the greater Downpatrick area not deserve it  A school where children regardless of ability can achieve their potential He continued: ldquoThe new school will cater for every child. No child will be disadvantaged or be selected to attend this new school. For once they will have control over their choice of post-primary education.ldquoWhat is proposed is a Catholic school, with a strong Catholic Lasallian ethos. No child will be turned away because of not making the threshold grade. They will wear the same unorm, access the same curriculum and extracurricular activities and be treated with the same care and respect that they currently receive in their respective schools.Mr Maguire added: ldquoThis is something that very few communities in Northern Ireland can avail of. The pupils of Downpatrick and beyond have amalgamated through collaboration at GCSE and GCE level. It is now up to the schools to come together and put their best foot forward..prettyPhoto

title: Football crazy siblings set to be future stars
story: A DOWNPATRICK brother and sister have the football world at their feet.Nine year-old Annie Montgomery and her  year-old brother Josh, are football crazy and both have been earmarked as stars of the future.Annie, a pupil at St Brigidrsquos Primary School, who plays for Rossglass County in the Downpatrick Youth Leaguersquos small sided games, has just been selected to take part in the IFArsquos Elite Girlsrsquo development programme.Not to be outdone, Josh, a pupil at De La Salle High School, who plays for Cltonville in the National League, has been selected for the Lisburn Youth League Select team to play in this yearrsquos prestigious Dublin Cup.Annie, a box-to-box midfielder, who has an eye for goals, started her career with Celtic Bhoys first kickers at age six, but she soon moved to Rossglass County, where her dad BJ played his football.ldquoShe really enjoys scoring goals and can play anywhere, said her father.ldquoAnnie was enjoying her time at Celtic Bhoys, but she moved to Rossglass to get more game time and hasnrsquot looked back. She spends hours out on the Red High pitch, which is just across the road and she and Josh just compliment each other.ldquoShe is a great wee worker, willing to learn the tricks of the trade and takes everything in her stride, he added.ldquoIdeally, Annie would drove to play in a girlsrsquo only side, but she knows how to mix it with the best come Sunday morning. She is in a mixed team and can handle herself.Josh, who also started out with Celtic Bhoys before moving to Downpatrick FC, was picked up by Solitude scouts after a series of trial games and he now attends training at the North Belfast club twice a week.ldquoHe has come on leaps and bounds since joining Cltonville, said his dad.ldquoHe has won the player of the year for the past two seasons in a row and just loves being part of the set-up at Cltonville. He also scores goals for fun, but doesnrsquot mind ping back a little to help out when his side lose possession, Mr Montgomery added.ldquoThe coaches at Cltonville have really helped him and he doesnrsquot mind the travelling up to Belfast three times a week. He would travel anywhere to get a game of football.Both Annie and Josh are fanatical Manchester United players and love nothing more than a trip to Old Trafford to see the Red Devils play.However, they have turned the football pitches at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School into their own theatre of dreams and the only way is up for the talented siblings..prettyPhoto

title: Former pupil at Old Dunumians meeting
story: A FORMER pupil of Down High School who is now head of one of the biggest charities in the island of Ireland will be the guest speaker at a meeting next week.Professor Peter McBride will address the Old Dunumians in Down High Schoolrsquos library on Thursday evening.Professor McBride was at Down High School from -. He has degrees in Science and Divinity and at Masters Level in Social Work, alongside further qualications and experience in the fields of business management, counselling and the management of psychological trauma.He is the chief executive of Inspire, which has almost , staff and a turnover in excess of poundm.He joined Inspire in  as the managing director of Carecall and has been chief executive since .Professor McBride is a trustee of BBC Children in Need, in which he chairs the nomination committee and the grants committee and is chair of Million and Me mdash a poundm initiative to support the development of mental health services for children.He is a trustee of NICVA where he serves as chair of the board and is also a trustee of The Wheel, NICVArsquos sister organisation in the Republic of Ireland.He also chairs the lsquoBeing Openrsquo group of the inquiry into hyponatraemia-related deathson behalf of the NI Department of Health.He has also been involved for over  years in the victims and survivors sector in Northern Ireland..prettyPhoto

title: French journalists visit fantastique Thrones locations
story: FRENCH travel journalists and bloggers have visited popular beauty spots in Co Down connected with the blockbuster Game of Thrones TV series.Some of Francersquos top media writers, who have a combined following of over six million people, were invited by Tourism NI to spend a few days visiting Tollymore Forest, Inch Abbey and Castle Ward, among others, recently.The fantasy epic has gained a cult following around the world in recent years and some of the locations used in the shooting of the series include Castle Ward and the nearby Audleyrsquos Castle, which dates from the th century.The journalists also stopped off at Cushendun, the Dark Hedges, Dunluce Castle and the Giantrsquos Causeway.Monica MacLaverty, Tourism Ireland Manager said: ldquoThe eighth and final season of Game of Thrones will air this spring, so we are taking every opportunity to highlight Northern Ireland as the lsquoHome of Thronesrsquo to fans in France and where around the world.ldquoThe visit of these top French travel writers and bloggers is an excellent opportunity to showcase Northern Ireland to a wide audience of fans and holidaymakers.ldquoTheir articles, posts and photos will be seen and shared by their readers and online followers, inspiring them to come and explore Northern Ireland for themselves.She added: ldquoTourism Ireland undertakes a busy publicity programme around the world each year to raise the profile of Northern Ireland ndash and visits by journalists and social influencers are a key element of that programme.Game of Thrones fever is on the rise once again, with anticipation mounting among fans everywhere about the long-awaited final season, which is set to begin in April..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C February 27%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash The Department of the Environmentrsquos Roads Division warned yesterday that staff cutbacks could substantially delay two new major schemes in Downpatrick.Divisional Roads boss Mr J D Kirk admitted that several proposed schemes will be hit, including a car park in the Irish Street Market Street area of Downpatrick and a realignment programme for Saul Street and Scotch Street.Mr Kirk claims that he does not have a large enough supervisory staff to carry out work which has been programmed.Mr Kirk stressed that the cutbacks could not have come at a worse time when the Roads Service is under heavy pressure to complete schemes and also to start several others which are in the pipeline.He explained that the long-awaited new pound, car park for Downpatrick now seemed certain to run into further dficulties and that the realignment programme will suffer from the staff shortages.Downpatrick councillors have hit out at the threat of further delays to local schemes. Cllr George Flinn was particularly outraged. ldquoI am amazed to hear of this and deplore any delays in schemes that should have been completed a long time ago., he said.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Ballynahinch Chamber of Commerce are to continue their efforts to have the townrsquos police station opened full time.The Chamberrsquos executive committee, who met recently, discussed an acknowledgment from RUC headquarters, saying they would look at the possibility. The committee agreed to pursue the matter.At the same meeting members expressed pleasure at the announcement that the Department of the Environment intend spending pound, on improved lighting in the town, but they showed deep concern over the Department of Educationrsquos decision not to provide a swimming pool for the town.Already local schools are up in arms about the decision, as the pool would have provided swimming facilities for over , pupils. However, the Chamber intend to follow it up and are to invite representatives of the ious schools to meet them in April to discuss the situation.DRUMAGHLIS mdash The future of Drumaghlis Primary School is causing problems for the South Eastern Education and Library Board. The Department of Education havenrsquot yet disclosed their intentions, in spite of having been told of strong feeling that it should not be closed.Mrs Ethel Smyth, a member of the maintained schools committee, was irritated by the lack of information from the Department.She said the school had  pupils and assumed maintained status in January of last year. In June members of the committee requested financial help from the Department to modernise the toilets abed were concerned to receive a letter asking their views on the schoolrsquos future.Mrs Smyth said that parents of children attending the school were totally opposed to its closure in view of the long distances by the pupils would have to travel to other schools.KILLYLEAGH mdash An emergency meeting of Killyleagh Young Farmersrsquo Club was held in the townrsquos Masonic hall this week.Twenty-six people were present, including a representative from YFC headquarters. The meeting was chaired by Mr Denis McAuley, from Downpatrick YFC. A y and informative discussion took place during which many helpful points were raised regarding the future of the club.The election of the senior officials and office bearers was completed and all posts were filled. Finally, after the interest shown in the club at the emergency meeting, members stressed that the look forward to a very successful year.STRANGFORD mdash The Department of Environment has proposed that crossing fares for the Strangford ferry should be increased.Ards Borough councillors were told this week that the Downpatrick DoE office, which administers the ferry, has recommended that fees should be increased in line with the rising costs of operating the service.If a new increase is implemented, it will mean that a passenger will pay p to use the ferry between Strangford and Portaferry instead of the present rate of p. The new cost for a motorcycle will be p instead of p car fares will go up to p from p vehicles up to two tons will pay pound mdash an increase of p and vehicles up to five tons will pay pound instead of pound..A letter to the council said that the Department believed that it was better to introduce ldquomodest annual increases rather than larger ones every few years. Councillors decided to consider the matter fully and to write to the Department expressing their views.NEWCASTLE mdash Mr Dermot Patrick Herlighy , of Clontarf, Dublin, died suddenly at Royal County Down Golf Club on Saturday morning from a coronary attack.The deceased was a member of the Irish international golfing party who were practising on the course at the weekend.BALLYGOWAN mdash Residents in Ballygowan have called for the removal of a water booster generator near the town which has created a traffic hazard for more than a year.The problem relates to huge booster which was erected on a bend on the Carrickmannon Road to increase pressure in the water supply for parts of the area.Local councillor Jim McBriar says he wants the generator removed before it causes a serious accident.ldquoThis booster may be serving a need until a proper replacement is provided, but local people want it removed because it is hazardous, he said.A spokesman for the Water Service said they had very little power in the situation. ldquoWe asked the Northern Ireland Electricity Service some time ago to provide a temporary booster until the water situation was sorted out, he said.ldquoHowever, it has been there for more than  months now and it should it up to them to remove it.Initially, the generator was only meant to operate temporarily, but now local people fear that it may stay there indefinitely.KILLINCHY mdash Mr Tom Pendry, the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State in the Northern Ireland Office with responsibility for Agriculture, visited Cuan Sea Fisheries Ltd, near Killinchy, on Saturday.Dr Jasper Parsons, general manager of Cuan Sea Fisheries, met Mr Pendry, and led him on a conducted tour of the oyster farm.Cuan Sea Fisheries, which employs a staff of eight, was established six years ago on the shores of Strangford Lough. Pacic oysters, imported as seed from hatcheries in England, are reared in the lough on trays and in nets.Interest in oyster farming grew in Northern Ireland in  after successful experimental work by the Department of Agriculturersquos Fisheries Division which showed that the Pacic oyster could thrive in Strangford Lough.CARRYDUFF mdash Plans are being drawn up for a new pedestrian crossing scheme in Carryduff.Residents in the area have been pressing for a controlled crossing system with traffic lights for some time and at last it looks s through work is in the pipeline.Members of Castlereagh Borough Council heard that there are plans for crossings on the Ballynahinch Road, Church Street and the Hillsborough Road.BALLYKINLAR mdash Downpatrick firemen answered a call to a gorse fire at Ballykinlar Camp on Saturday. Approximately six acres of gorse had been extinguished on arrival.CASTLEWELLAN mdash The game fishing season begins shortly, but anglers wishing to use Castlewellan Lake will have to wait another month.Although the Department of Agriculture have  game and mixed fisheries to offer anglers, , including Castlewellan, will not open until April  to facilitate spring stocking.Already an experiment to test ious methods of stocking is being conducted in Castlewellan Lake. This involves the tagging of a large number of fish.SPA mdash A capacity audience filled Ballynahinch High Schoolrsquos assembly hall to see Spa Young Farmersrsquo Clubrsquos presentation of George Shielsrsquo evergreen comedy play, The New Gossoon.The cast did the author and themselves proud with their presentation. So well received was the play that inquiries are already being made with regard to taking it on a short local tour. The play was produced by Mr Cecil Orr, the club president..prettyPhoto

title: Mollie cooks up a treat in university business school
story: A KILLYLEAGH student is celebrating success after winning three top awards at the Ulster University Business School.Mollie Cunningham, who recently graduated with a BSc Honours degree in Consumer Management and Food Innovation, recorded the hat-trick at the annual Department of Hospitality and Tourism Awards held at the Magee Campus.Her awards included the Suki Tea Food Policy Award for achieving the highest mark in the Contemporary Food Policy module the Food Innovation Award for high level performance in the Food Innovation module and the Consumer CouncilAward for excelling in the Consumer Issues module.Speaking at the awards ceremony, Professor Una McMahon-Beattie, Head of Department, said: ldquoIn conjunction with our industry partners, the Department of Hospitality and Tourism is delighted to celebrate and recognise the excellence of our students.ldquoWe are very proud of their achievements and are confident that with the current growthin the local hospitality and tourism sectors, our graduates are well equipped to take on the challenges of managing and leading in these competitive market environments..prettyPhoto

title: O’Hare hat trick secures victory
story: A SUBLIME Donal OrsquoHare hat-trick at Glennon Brothers Peare Park, Longford, on Sunday reignited Downrsquos promotion aspirations.The Burren assassin was in a class of his own against the league leaders, but it also took some heroic goalkeeping from Castlewellanrsquos Rory Burns to keep Down on track for their third win on the bounce.Burns, who plays in midfield for his club, was inspirational between the sticks and in addition to keeping out another penalty mdash his second in three games mdash he produced several outstanding saves to deny Longford a goal they craved. Longford settled first and leading marksman Darren Gallagher registered the first score with a free in the fourth minute, but despite a lot of possession, the home side struggled to get scores on the board.Downrsquos defensive cover was superb with Saulrsquos Pierce Laverty making a more than impressive debut at half back.He received great support from Downpatrickrsquos Gerard Collins, Castlewellanrsquos Colm Flanagan and Bryansfordrsquos Ruairi Wells as Down closed up shop.Mind you, Down also struggled early on to get scores, but all that changed in the th minute.A measured long ball in from Caolan Mooney was ruthlessly pounced upon by OrsquoHare and he finished to the net with panache.Points from Gallagherand Liam Connerton drew Longford level in the th minute, but Down responded in style and regained the initiative with unanswered points from OrsquoHare , Conor Poland and corner back Gerard Collins.Longford had a goal chance in the th minute when Darren Quinn carved out an opening for the lurking Gallagher, but Burns made am outstanding save to deny the danger man and send Down in at the break with a - to - lead.Paddy Tallyrsquos men stretched their lead to seven within one minute of the second half when another long ball in, this time from Poland, picked out OrsquoHare and he grabbed his and his sidersquos second goal.Longford got a much needed point from Connor Berry in the th minute, but minutes later Burns denied Gallagher. Longford were made to rue those missed goal chances in the th minute when Jerome Johnston found Daniel Guinness and he played it to OrsquoHare who got his third goal.Berry kicked over a free in the th minute and two minutes later Longford had a chance for a goal when they were awarded a penalty after Quinn was fouled. Up stepped Gallagher, but his spot-kick was pushed out for a rsquo by the brilliant Burns. Gallagher made no mistake with the rsquo, but Longford really needed a goal at this stage.Jerome Johnstonand Daniel Guinness added points to their score while Longford got consolation points from Gallagher and Connerton.Down are now level on points with Louth, but behind on score dference. They have a chance to reduce that gap when they entertain Offaly at Pairc Esler on Saturday night.Down: R Burns, G Collins , R Wells, R McAleenan, P Laverty, C Flanagan, D OrsquoHagan, J Flynn, C Mooney, R Johnston, C Poland , C McGrady, D OrsquoHare , C Harrison, K McKernan. Subs: D Guinnessfor McGrady, B OrsquoHagan for Johnston, C Maginn for Flynn, J Johnstonfor Harrison, B McArdle for R Wells.Longford: P Collum, D Quinn, A Farrell, B OrsquoFarrell, CP Smyth, B McKeon, D Mimnagh, D Gallagher , M Quinn, S Donohoe, P Hanley, P Lynn, D Doherty, L Connerton , M Hughes. Subs: D McElligott for Donohoe, C Berryfor Hanley, Hagan for Lynn, J McGivney for Hughes, P Fox for Mimnagh..prettyPhoto

title: Plans for more hotel bedrooms in Downpatrick
story: PLANS have been lodged to provide a number of new hotel rooms in Downpatrick.Permission is being sought by the Downpatrick Property Trust to convert a number of existing flats in Market Street and Irish Street to provide what is being described as ldquooverflow hotel bedroom accommodation and a number of hotel serviced apartments.In addition, permission is being sought to convert existing ground floor retail accommodation in Irish Street to a wheelchair accessible bedroom with an en-suite shower and toilet.The application has been lodged with Newry, Mourne and Down Council planners who are currently examining its detail.News of the additional hotel bedroom accommodation has been welcomed by Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran.Mr Curran said there was a ldquopressing need for more bed nights, not only in the town but across the wider district.He added: ldquoI welcome this proposal as it will help meet a pressing need in the town centre for hotel bed space.News of the proposal to convert existing flats and a retail unit to provide new hotel beds in Downpatrick comes after the local authority announced that it is keen to support new tourist accommodation schemes across the district.The council plans to develop its own financial assistance programme to support eligible costs for new tourism developments that have secured planning permission, with financial support available to those who submit detailed business cases to the local authority.Local politicians have consistently highlighted the lack of overnight accommodation across the district and believe that providing new hotel and bed and breakfast provision can help create new jobs and boost the local economy.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has placed tourism at the top of its agenda and is striving to attract more international visitors to stay overnight across the district..prettyPhoto

title: Popular St Mary’s principal retires
story: IF Mrs Sheila Darling has a mantra, it would be ldquoevery child matters.The principal of St Maryrsquos High School in Downpatrick believes that her school exists solely to bring out the very best of every child who comes over their door.After  years as a teacher and just over eight years as principal of the girlsrsquo school on the Ardglass Road, she is retiring tomorrow.A special mass of celebration was held yesterday to bid farewell to Mrs Darling. Taking part in the mass were Canon Sean Rogan, who is a former school governor, family friend Fr Seamus McGinley and Diocesan priest Canon Noel Conway.Among those attending were Mr Eamonn McGrady, chairman of the schoolrsquos board of governors, and Mrs Darlingrsquos husband, Martin.Mrs Darling is leaving the school in the equally capable hands of the incoming principal, Miss Rosemary McLoughlin, who is the current vice-principal.Having worked at St Maryrsquos since , Miss McLoughlin is the perfect person to steward the school over the next few years as St Maryrsquos faces the prospect of joining the new lsquosuper schoolrsquo proposed by the CCMS for Downpatrick for .Itrsquos a challenge that Mrs Darling wishes she was around to oversee.ldquoRetiring is something thatrsquos really quite bittersweet for me because I will really miss the school and everyone here, and seeing the girls every morning, said Mrs Darling.ldquoBut of course I wonrsquot miss the administration. I actually thought of leaving last year but as we had our th anniversary I wasnrsquot going to leave before I had handled all of that.ldquoI think itrsquos nice for a principal to take over a school a little bit before the begining of an academic year.She sees the proposed new lsquosuper schoolrsquo as a great opportunity for the school and its students.ldquoI would have absolutely loved the challenge to ensure that every single child going into that school would be properly catered for and would be treated respectfully and fairly, she said.ldquoNot only our girls but that the children from the other schools would be treated equally and fairly.When Mrs Darling looks at her students, she unrelentingly sees promise and potential in each and every one and makes no apology for it.She is well-known for her high expectations for the students.ldquoI believe I have helped the children here to raise their aspirations, to hold their heads up high, be proud of who they are and realise that they are as good as anyone , that they are capable of being successful in their own right and to bring that success to their families and their communities, said Mrs Darling.ldquoOur children in this school have seen GCSE and A-Level results increase year on year. They know that I expect them to achieve. I expect them to work hard and to keep going until they get it right and until they get to where they want to be.ldquoTheir parents have been a wonderful support to me as a principal. They have been very engaged and we have travelled the same path together. We have built a very constructive partnership to support their children to be the very best they can be.ldquoItrsquos very important to me that every child coming through the door of this school know that they are valued, they are cherished and that they are provided with a first-class education, to progress and to be the best that they can be.Mrs Darling speaks highly of her teaching staff and all the staff who help make St Maryrsquos the school it is today.ldquoI was very warmly welcomed into the Downpatrick area and the parents were extremely supportive. We have a wonderful board of governors who have been very supportive in working with me and the vision I had for the school and Irsquom very fortunate to have had the staff that I had, she added.Like many other teachers, she was called into education due to being inspired by her own teachers from Newtownhamilton in Co Armagh where she was raised.ldquoI always wanted to be a teacher, recalled Mrs Darling. ldquoI think I was fortunate to have wonderful teachers as a pupil and was really inspired by many of them. I could see the impact that some of those teachers had on people.Having qualied in  from Jordanstown, Mrs Darling began her teaching career in a co-ed secondary school in Kent before moving to a girlsrsquo school in Londonrsquos Bexley Heath borough.A teacher of Mathematics, Home Economics and Food Sciences, she ed home with her husband and worked at a school in Limerick for a few years before coming north again to take up a position at St Paulrsquos High School in Bessbrook in .Leaving as head of the junior school in , Mrs Darling was vice-principal of St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan before taking up her appointment with St Maryrsquos in November, .Having held such a pivotal position in a community for so long, she knows that retirement will take so getting used to but she is well-prepared, as ever.ldquoI do feel that itrsquos a privilege to lead a school as you are in a position to make a real dference but I will certainly not miss the journey in the morning and the driving through the snow and all the other things, of which I have certainly done plenty.ldquoI live in Camlough so itrsquos a -mile round trip every day. But then I have really enjoyed the drive through the Mournes in the sunlight. It can be absolutely glorious. The sunrises are amazing, as are the sunsets, and I have seen both of them on working days.Retirement will give her and her husband a chance to travel and spend more time with their daughter and son who live in Boston and London respectively, and to increase her leisure activities.ldquoI donrsquot intend to sit on a chair, she said. ldquoI will be working with a number of charities to support them and I certainly hope I will be in a position to make a dference in some of the charities.ldquoI hope to work with Sister Consilio [who runs an addiction treatment centre] with her work in Downpatrick.ldquoFrom my perspective, it enables me to carry on the Mercy tradition which is so tangible in this school plus I have worked in this community for eight and a half years and I want to give back.Her parting words to the school and colleagues were: ldquoI have always wanted every child in this school to feel they really do matter, that they will be cared for here and their lives will be enriched by the experiences they have here..prettyPhoto

title: Programme of events to mark St Patrick’s Day
story: THE countdown is on to this yearrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations in Downpatrick.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has lined up a wide range of events, concerts and activities, culminating in the annual cross community parade which will take place on Sunday, March  mdash despite the fact that the major religious events in honour of the patron saint have been switched to the following day.Earlier this month, the Recorder revealed that a number of traders in Downpatrick were angry that the decision to hold the carnival parade on the Sunday was taken without consulting them.With March  falling on the Sabbath, the annual St Patrickrsquos pilgrimage walk from Saul Church into the centre of the town and the traditional cross-community ecumenical service at Down Cathedral will both take place on the following day.The flagship Downpatrick carnival parade has been held before on a Sunday when the former Down Council was the organiser but previously when St Patricks Day fell on a Sunday, the cross-community spectacular has been moved to the day after.The decision to hold the Downpatrick parade on March  means the town will now host two major events on the same day, with the hugely popular Jimmys K road race taking place in the morning ahead of the festival parade starting at pm.Three weeks ago traders said Downpatrick is always busy in the lead-up to the parade with the majority of themdoing relatively well on what is the townrsquos busiest day of the year in attracting visitors.Some in the business community argue that traders will ldquolose out as the parade is taking place on Sunday as the majority will not have the opportunity to enjoy the same income they would expectthe event was held on a Saturday or Monday.Several traders said they were not surprised that council officials did not consult them before making a decision to hold the cross-community parade on the Sunday. They insist they should have been asked for their view. Some in the business community argued that visitors are not going to come to Downpatrick on both March  and .With the March  parade set to go ahead as planned, the local authority has confirmed that festivities kick off on Sunday, March , at pm with the popular Saints and Scholars Concert in Down Cathedral.The concert, which is hosted by the All Lives Are Precious organisation, features Liam Lawton, Malachi Cush, Karl McGuckin and Matthew Campbell.Tickets are free and available on a first come, first serve basis from Downpatrick Visitor Information Centre, Down Cathedral and Saint Patrickrsquos Parish Office, in the town.Local council chairman Mark Murnin said he was delighted to see the ldquowonderful line-up of events and activities in Downpatrick.ldquoOur district is acknowledged as the home of Saint Patrick. We are celebrating that link through colourful processions, music, dance and entertainment and this will be a terric day out for everyone, he added.The parade, which will be compered by local performer Connor Martin, includes a vintage car cavalcade, floats, community groups and bands.Participants are due to leave the Ardglass Road at pm and make their way to Lower Market Street car park via Edward Street, John Street, Irish Street and Market Street.The entertainment at Saint Patrick Square features a fabulous array of free activities including face painting, walkabout characters, arts and crafts, balloon modelling, a reptile petting zoo, Irish dancing and live performances from local performers.Gracing the stage will be Newcastle Comhaltas, Cora Kelly and the Just Adam Band, while for those wishing to stay indoors, there will be free childrenrsquos activities hosted in Journey Church in Market Street.There will also be a special St Patrickrsquos Day programme of events at the Down County Museum between am to pm and in Down Arts Centre between .am and pm, with all the St Patrickrsquos events supported by Tourism NI and The Executive Office.For festival programme details, including church services, other local events and parade routes visit www.saintpatrickscountry..prettyPhoto

title: Saints lose to league leaders
story: SAINTFIELD United hosted league leaders Aquinas in a much-anticipated clash of two of the top teams in the league.It was the visitors who drew first blood when the first corner of the game was kept alive at the back post and struck into the net to make the score -.The Saints tried to get their passing going, but were snuffed out by their opponents who didnrsquot want to allow the hosts to settle.They continued to cause trouble from set-pieces and Saintfield paid the price when once again a free kick was kept alive and the visitors were first to the second ball to make the score -.Saintfield now faced a great uphill battle, they kept trying to play their football, but chances were few and far between for both sides.Saintfield came out fast in the second half, looking to put their opponents onto the back foot and get back into the game.They thought they had when some good play down the right led to a shot from Adam Childs that hit the underside of the bar and appeared to cross the line, but not in the eyes of the referee who ruled against the hosts and the scoreline stayed -.The game was even throughout, the only other noteworthy chance falling to James Sofley who couldnrsquot find a way past the Aquinas lsquokeeper.The Saints will be looking to bounce back and get their revenge when they travel to Rathmore to face the same opponents this weekend..prettyPhoto

title: Sally Ann is spot on
story: FORTY years of patient waiting ended for Spa member Sally Ann Douglas last week when she recorded her first hole-in-one of her golfing career.The clubrsquos former lady captain hit the perfect shot at the par three eight hole in a game partnered by Joe and Marlene Crawford.ldquoI used a pitching wedge and Marlene and I watched it all the way until it landed in the cup, she said. ldquoI just thought, brilliant. At long last.But golf is in Sally Annrsquos blood. Her -year old mother, Dorothy Walsh, is still playing on a regular basis at her home club at Rathfarnham, Dublin, having taken up the game  years ago.Spa ladies will recall how Dorothy was guest of honour at Sally Annrsquos Lady Captainrsquos Day in  where she charmed everyone with her friendly personality and good humour..prettyPhoto

title: Success for Down GAA at anniversary Scór
story: DOWN GAA did the th anniversary of Scoacuter proud at the weekend.The format and competitions may have changed and evolved over the years, but the enthusiasm for the preservation of Irish cultural heritage has certainly not waned.On Friday night the crowd in St Michaelrsquos Hall, Finnis, for the East Down finals may have been small, but they were treated to high class entertainment in the solo singing, recitation, ballad group and leiacuteruiacute statisecategories with the winner and runner-up in each going through to the county finals.At the South Down finals in Mayobridge Community Centre on Saturday night the packed house was treated to an extraordinary bill of fare reminiscent of days gone by.The adjudicators in both isional finals had very tough jobs on their hands and it is unfortunate that some competitors had to miss out on the opportunity to compete in the county finals, which take place in St Patrickrsquos College, Scarva Banbridge, this Friday at .pm.Those taking part will be as follows:Ceili dancing mdash Cumann Pheadar Naofa Football, Cumann Pheadar Naofa Hurling, Mayobridge, Clann na Banna and Clonduff.Solo singing mdash Holly McKay , Seamus Gartland , Vivienne Murphyand Eimear Magee .Recitation mdash Sharlene Neeson , Kathleen Lucas , Clare McCartanand Donna Feeney .Ballad Group ndash Dundrum, Bryansford, Mayobridge and Cumann Pheadar NaofaLeiacuteruiacute Statise mdashDarragh Cross, Drumaness, Atticall and Rostrevor.Instrumental music mdash Clonduff, Cumann Pheadar Naofa and Mayobridge.Set dancing mdash Clonduff, Cumann Pheadar Naofa Football and Cumann Pheadar Naofa Hurling.With almost a full complement of competitors in each discipline taking part in the County Finals anticipation is already running at fever pitch.Down GAA Scor Committee wishes to clubs for hosting the competitions and everyone who contributed towards ensuring that they ran successfully.St Patrickrsquoc College, Banbridge, will also be the venue for an Ulster semi-final on Sunday, March .The county table quiz will take place in Burren on Friday, March , starting at pm. It only takes a maximum of four people to enter a team and it is hoped that clubs who were unable to field competitors in the lsquostage-basedrsquo competitions will enter a team. title: outstanding quality at second calf fair

title: ruas winter fair to become important dairy showcase
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valSecuring a time-limit on the controversial Irish border backstop would effectively mean there is no longer a backstop, DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds has suggested.In an interview with the News Letter, the DUP deputy leader said any changes to Theresa May’s Brexit deal must be legally binding or they “will not cut the mustard” with his party.Nigel Dodds said that a time limit on the backstop would nully it and make it inoperableSignicantly, while he reiterated his party’s stance that the backstop “has to go”, Mr Dodds also stated that placing a time-limit on the arrangement would “nully” it and make it inoperable.“A backstop is an all-enduring, forever trap,” the North Belfast MP said, adding: “It isn’t a backstopit is time-limited.”The remarks come following reports that the North Belfast MP has been involved in drawing up proposals that could yield a breakthrough over the thorny issue of the backstop.When askedhis party would back the withdrawal agreementthey were given legal assurances the backstop would be temporary in nature, Mr Dodds said: “The bottom line is that we cannot accept anything that doesn’t have a legally binding way out of the backstop.“The prime minister has set out in the Commons that there has to be legally binding change and we are going to hold her to that. If there isn’t legally binding change,it is just more assurances or guarantees about the temporary nature of the backstop, that is not going to work.”According to the Sunday Times, the hardline European Research Groupof Tory MPs have indicated they will support the PM’s Brexit dealtheir demands are met, including a legally binding mechanism to escape the backstop.• Morning View: DUP reaction to backstop will be central to fate of UKIn private talks with Attorney General Geoffrey Cox, the ERG called for a legally binding mechanism to escape the backstop, with a clear exit route and an unambiguous rewrite of the language in the government’s legal advice, the newspaper said. The demands were drawn up in conjunction with Mr Dodds, it was reported.Last week, DUP Brexit spokesperson Sammy Wilson appeared to indicate his party would be willing to accept a time-limited backstop. His remarks led some commentators to suggest that the DUP was softening its stance on Brexit, with former UUP leader Lord Empey accusing the party of “slithering towards a fudge” on Brexit.Jay Donnelly sex picture ‘still in possession of others’Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald hoping to hold talks with chief constable Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Speaking to the News Letter yesterday, Mr Dodds said his party was going to “examine very carefully and critically” whatever concessions the government manages to secure from Brussels.“We will be guided by what the effect of it is. Does it legally change the withdrawal agreement  That is what is clear and important,” he added. “If it doesn’t change the withdrawal agreement and the attorney general can’t change his opinion, it won’t cut the mustard as far as we are concerned.“We have set out a series of tests which measure up to what the prime minister committed to as part of the Brady amendment. We will measure whatever is brought back against those tests.”According to the Sunday Times, the three tests the government must meetthe prime minister is to receive the backing of the ERG and DUP include: • A “clearly worded, legally binding, treaty-level clause which unambiguously overrides” the text of the withdrawal agreement• Language that “must go beyond simply re-emphasising reinterpreting the temporary nature of the backstop” and a change to Cox’s legal advice that it would “endure indefinitely”• A “clear and unconditional route out of the backstoptrade talks fail”, which could mean “a time limit or a unilateral exit mechanism”.Meanwhile, Mr Dodds dismissed allegations that his party had softened its stance on the backstop.He also stated that a no-deal scenario was “still better than a bad deal,” adding: “As far as we are concerned the withdrawal agreement is the worst position of all.”TUV leader Jim Allister said no unionist should be prepared to countenance the backstop “for even a single day,” adding: “It is not about the duration, it is about sovereignty and there is no room for compromise when it comes to sovereignty.“Once you accept the principle of the backstop, you have accepted the principle that NI should be treated dferently from the rest of the UK.”Irish premier Leo Varadkar yesterday said his government and the EU are happy to offer clarications and assurances on the withdrawal agreement, to help get the accord over the line.The attorney general and Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay are toto Brussels today for further talks.• Morning View: DUP reaction to backstop will be central to fate of UKJPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings  Terms and Conditions  Disclaimer  Privacy policy    d.onerror  d.onload  d.src  ["secure-uk.imrworldwide cgi-bin m ciuk-hcgccsi", escape, "rp", escape, "tscompactrnd", .getTime].join

If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valA call for direct rule for Northern Ireland has been made during a budget debate in the House of Commons.DUP MP Emma Little-Pengellyasked when Westminster would decide direct rule was "necessary", now Northern Ireland has been without a ing executive since January .She asked the question as MPs were debating the Northern Ireland Budget Bill at Westminster.Mrs Little-Pengelly said: "At which point will the Secretary of State accept this is an entirely unsustainable position "The people of Northern Ireland are in a really dficult position,Sinn Fein boycotting the Northern Ireland Assembly ... and the Secretary of State and this Government is refusing to put in place a direct rule, which, though not desirable, is necessary."We are now into several years of this type of process - theres no scrutiny, no democratic accountability - when is that going to change "Northern Irish Secretary Karen Bradley said she would not be moving to direct rule.She said: "We are in a very unsatisfactory position and I would rather we were not doing this this way."But in order to ensure public services continue to be delivered and in order to ensure civil servants in Northern Ireland do have the statutory underpinning they need for the spending, that is why we are taking this budget Bill."DUP MP Gavin Robinsonsaid there was "no need" for an emergency Bill, asking "when in the last two months has there been any genuine prospect of the Assembly being restored" to necessitate the Bill being fast-tracked.Ms Bradley responded: "We have to be aware of the constitutional precedents that are set by changing the way we scrutinise these Bills..."What I want to see is those politicians in Northern Ireland doing the right thing, coming back into Stormont, forming the executive so that all of those proper processes can be applied."But I dont think we should kid ourselves there is some sort of substitute arrangement that is going to offer a dferent approach - we have to see devolved government restored in Stormont."Jay Donnelly sex picture ‘still in possession of others’Broken down vehicle causing delays on M Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Ms Bradley admitted that budgets being set from Westminster would lead to "perverse outcomes" for the people of Northern Ireland after a Labour MP raised the issue of childcare.Jess Phillipssaid she had recently been to visit and was "shocked" to find out free childcare was not available, and there was nothing in the bill allocated to spend in that area.Ms Bradley said the allocations "are in line with the advice from the Permanent Secretaries as to the monies they need".But she added: "That leads to perverse outcomes, that leads to things not being as we would like them in Northern Ireland."It leads to dferences in Northern Ireland, it leads to the end of programmes that we may otherwise have wanted to see continue, but without a minister to direct that, those programmes do finish."She said the answer is "devolved government in Northern Ireland", adding "there is no alternatives".The DUPs Mrs Little-Pengelly also raised the issue of a lack of money for childcare, saying the planned rollout of the Governments flagship  hours of free care policy had stalled without the Assembly sitting.She said: "There cannot be a decision on  hours free childcare, despite all of the work in the department, because there is no minister there to take it."Shadow secretary of state for Northern Ireland Tony Lloyd said he did not want to see direct rule, adding: "We simply cant allow this vacuum to continue in this way, decisions are not being made."He said the "hope is in a restoration of the Stormont structures becausewe give up on that were giving up actually on at least the principle of what the Good Friday agreement delivered".Mr Lloyd said: "Weve got to see a lot more concerted effort to get people round the table to try to break that log jam."If we start waving the spectre of direct rule at this point then we are saying that were giving up on power-sharing."He added: "Of course the Labour Government did bring in direct rule so none of us can say this can never happen, what I will say though is were not there yet but we are in the position where weve got to see greater activity from the secretary of state, yes of course from the leaders of the political parties."I do honestly doubt this Governments capacity ... iIf the Prime Minister herself is only so preoccupied with Brexit that she has no time to look at devolution to Northern Ireland that is a fundamental political mistake that we will come to rue for time to come."try catch  TrendingIN PICTURES:  things title: santander penarth branch set to close
story: The branch is one of  that Santander has announced will close as the company says it plans to reshape to suit the way customers are choosing to carry out their banking.Santanderrsquos future branch network will be made up of a combination of larger branches offering improved community facilities to support local businesses and customers, and smaller branches using the latest technology to offer customers more convenient access to banking services.The company has consulted its trade unions on the proposed changes and will seek to find alternative roles for the , colleagues affected.In order to deliver a branch network for the future,  Santander branches will be refurbished over the next two years through an investment of poundm. The refurbishments will include a range of changes with a focus on personal service, convenience and community engagement.Susan Allen, head of retail and business banking, said: ldquoThe way our customers are choosing to bank with us has changed dramatically in recent years, with more and more customers using online and mobile channels. As a result, we have had to take some very dficult decisions over our less visited branches, and those where we have other branches in close proximity.ldquoWe will support customers of closing branches to find alternative ways to bank with us that best suit their inidual needs. We are also working alongside our unions to support colleagues through these changes and to find alternative roles for those impacted wherever possible.ldquoWe continue to believe that branches have a vital role to play and we will be refurbishing  of our branches over the next two years. title: pier  to re open under new company
story: Pier  Limited ceased trading on January  this year after Cardf insolvency firm Begbies Traynor confirmed it was going into liquidation.However, Stephen Jones, who owns company Sansemea Limited, has taken over the restaurant and said "nothing is changing" with how it operates.The company also bought the name Pier  and have retained original staff members and chefs.Mr Jones also said that all customers who booked at the restaurant or bought gt vouchers before Pier  Limited closed will be honoured by the new restaurant."The restaurant was in need of refurbishment," said Mr Jones. "It was struggling because all of the equipment was  years old so everything was obsolete."I decided to give it a go and take it over and bought Pier . We took it over on January  and needed an interim period where a lot of money and work was put into the refurbishment."We held interviews with the former staff and we have most of them working here again now. We also have three of five chefs that were at the restaurant previously, including a top chef who has worked in some of the best restaurants in the world."Mr Jones said the restaurant will retain certain features, and the new menu will have some classic dishes that have been the most popular at the venue. He said all the work put into renovating the kitchen, honouring customers and other bits of work has cost around pound, altogether, but believes Pier  is worth it."I have been eating at Pier  myself for  years before this investment," Mr Jones said. The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."And French President Emmanuel Macron also said the agreement was "not re-negotiable", in comments just moments before MPs voted.The Commons approved a cross-party amendment, tabled by Midlands MPs Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, rejecting a no-deal Brexit by  to .The vote is not legally binding on the government but will impose massive political pressure on the prime minister to delay Brexit from its scheduled date of March she cannot secure a new deal from Brussels.The PM told MPs: "I agree that we should not leave without a deal. However, simply opposing no-deal is not enough to stop it."The Government will now redouble its efforts to get a deal that this House can support."There was uproar in the chamber as she said: "There is limited appetite for such a change in the EU and negotiating it will not be easy. But in contrast to a fortnight ago, this House has made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement."Mrs May said she would seek "legally binding changes to the Withdrawal Agreement that deal with concerns on the backstop while guaranteeing noto a hard border". article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: huge education revamp in wales revealed
story: The new Welsh curriculum has been in development for a number of years, and now details of the changes the Welsh Government is proposing to make have been revealed.Among them are for traditional subject boundaries to be eliminated and replaced with a series of lsquoAreas of Learning and Experiencersquo, or AOLEs, covering the humanities, health and wellbeing, science and technology, languages, literacy and communications, expressive arts, and maths.Schools will continue to be required by law to teach both English and Welsh, along with religious studies and relationships and sexuality education, while literacy, numeracy and digital competence will be required for pupils aged up to .But religious studies will be revamped to include non-religious world views such as humanism and, as announced earlier this month, Welsh will no longer be classed as a second language, but placed on an equal footing with English.Meanwhile, the current key stages will be scrapped and replaced with lsquoprogression stepsrsquo measured at ages five, eight, ,  and , with assessment based on an inidual pupilrsquos progression, taking their own circumstances into account.The Welsh Government has said the proposals represent ldquothe biggest shake-up of Walesrsquo curriculum since the s.Education minister Kirsty Williams said: ldquoWe want a curriculum that focuses also on equality as well as quality to ensure our young people leave school as confident iniduals, empathetic iniduals and ready to play a full le in the world of work, in the world of Wales ndash indeed, as citizens of the world.Ms Williams added the new curriculum, which is being developed alongside teachers from across Wales, will come into force for primary schools and year seven pupils in September , meaning it will be fully rolled out across all year groups by . story: Cardf and Vale University Health Board also reported five unexpected deaths of patients known to mental health services, while  of the incidents related to patients suffering bed sores, or pressure damage.The health board has also received a report from a coroner about a patient who took a deliberate overdose in an in-patient ward.lsquoSerious incidentsrsquo- eventssuch as unexpected or avoidable deaths, permanent harm to patients, visitors or members of the public, or incidents which threaten an organisationrsquos ability to deliver ongoing healthcare ndash are regularly published by the health board and reported to Welsh Government.Most serious incidents occur at University Hospital of Wales, the countryrsquos biggest, followed by University Llandough, a report to the health board says.In November and December, seven patients suffered serious injury after falling ndash two of whom died. The deaths has been reported to the coroner.It comes as almost , patient accidents or falls were reported between November  and December .Of the five unexpected deaths to patients known to mental health services, one was found hanging at home but the cause of deaths of the other patients are not yet confirmed.One dental patient was diagnosed withsquamous cell carcinoma ndash a form of skin cancer ndash having previously been downgraded from urgent to routine.Another patient suffered a stroke after ldquofollow-up processes were not followed and had not started blood thinning treatment, while another patient died whilst on the cardiac surgery waiting list.In another serious incident, an eye disorder patientrsquos sight ldquodeteriorated signicantly after not being offered a follow-up appointment.A regulation  report ndash which is sent to organisations when a coroner believes that action should be taken to prevent further deaths ndash has also been sent to the health board since the end of November.The report relates to an inquest in which the coroner concluded that a patient died after taking a deliberate overdose of his prescribed medication on an in-patient ward at University Hospital of Wales.The medication was not locked away in his bedside cupboard, which contravened the medicines code patient property policies, a health board report says.The health board report says: ldquoThe management of patientrsquos own medication is one which presents a particular challenge in the healthcare environment. Following the incident the UHB has carried out a benchmarking exercise across the UK and it does not appear that there is anyone centre that has managed to put an effective solution in place.ldquoWhile patients are always encouraged to hand over all medication or to send it home with family, there are many practical issues that make this dficult to implement and monitor robustly. Medication is the patientrsquos own property and they can refuse to hand it over should they wish. Staff would of course always have a discussion with the patient and the family with regards to the risk.ldquoIt is not possible for staff to monitor patientsrsquo property on a continuous basis and there are occasions when family members bring in additional property for patients while they are in hospital and this may include medication.ldquoThe UHB has submitted a response to the coroner and will continue to benchmark in order to find an effective solution.No new lsquoNever Eventsrsquo took place between November and December.Of the , falls reported betweenNovember  and December , % resulted in no harm, or minor harm.In December , more than  falls were reported ndash but this was the lowest monthly figure for that period.The health board is developing a strategy to reduce falls and reviewing prevention and management of bed sores.New guidance from the Welsh Government will mean fewer pressure damage incidents will be reported as lsquoSerious Incidentsrsquo, a health board report says.Patient approval remains high with the arearsquos two main hospitals as surveys suggest % are satisfied with their experience atUniversity Hospital of Llandough, and % of patients are satisfied atUniversity Hospital of Wales.A spokeswoman for Cardf and Vale University Health Board said: ldquoIn line with our duty of candour we report allseriousincidentsto Welsh Government, the public and to our board in line with best practice.ldquoWelsh Government guidance requires us to report unexpected deaths of patients who are known to mental health services and die unexpectedly or experienceseriousharm in a community setting. Patients and their families are made aware ofincidentsand are kept informed during investigations and discussions with our clinical teams.ldquoThe increased reporting of pressure damage reflects a period of education and training of staff to improve the quality of data being recorded.ldquoAllincidentsare fully investigated and appropriate actions are taken to reduce the risk of recurrence in the future. This enables clinical boards and the corporate teams to identy areas of good practice but also to identy emerging trends and issues that require action in order to improve safety and quality of services. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: new animated dog from welsh ambulance service informs people when to call
story: The animation, which forms part of the #WoodyWise campaign, launched on Monday, February  to raise awareness of the role of the ambulance service and how to make sensible choices when looking for health advice.Director of partnerships and engagement, Estelle Hitchon, said she hoped the animations would help engage and inform the public.She said: ldquoWhen someone feels unwell, particularly at the weekend or overnight, it can be dficult to know where to turn and phoning for an ambulance or turning up to an emergency unit can feel like the only options.ldquoIn the same way, dealing with minor injuries and illnesses can tie up ambulance resources, taking them away from patients who genuinely need our help.ldquoThe Woody animations take a number of scenarios with which we are all familiar and show why ringing for an ambulance sometimes is not right the choice, especially when it comes to a minor injury or illness.ldquoWe receive many calls from people who could have used NHS Direct Wales, the  service, their local pharmacy or a minor injuries unit, but instead chose to call an ambulance. Dealing with this type of call prevents our staff from dealing with genuine emergencies.ldquoCalling an ambulance when you donrsquot need one wastes time and resources which could have been better spent responding someone genuinely in need of the high level clinical care ambulance crews provide. Ambulances are not a taxi service and arriving at hospital by ambulance does not mean yoursquoll be seen quicker."She added: ldquoIf someone is seriously ill or injured and their le is at risk, you should call  immediately. For those minor illnesses and injuries which are less serious, we hope Woody the dog helps people realise that there are other, more appropriate, services available. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new festival of discovery calls for folk dancers from penarth
story: The Llangollen International Eisteddfod will break with tradition, partnering with the new Festival of Discovery.It is the first time since its creation in  that Llangollen will allow another event to act as a qualier.A total of  troupes of folk dancers will be given the chance to compete for a share of pound, ndash and to perform at Llangollen, which helped launch the careers of world stars like Sir Bryn Terfel, Luciano Paotti and Placido Domingo.The Eisteddfodrsquos acting musical director, Edward-Rhys Harry, said: ldquoThis partnership with the Festival of Discovery is a first for us and is about reaching out into the community and forging links with other cultural events.ldquoDance is very important to us at Llangollen and we are very well represented from an international point of view and we hope this will encourage a stronger entry from within Wales, across all ages, no holds barred.The Festival of Discovery Wales will take place at the Anglesey Showground from Thursday, May , to Saturday, June .Entries must be in by March . title: chance to join artists to help build penarth winter carnival
story: There will be open workshops hosted in the days running up to the carnival, exploring activity ideas, making costumes, masks and more.The workshops, traditionally known as mas camps, are sponsored by Waterloo Tea Rooms and will be attended by carnival artists from the Butetown Carnival. The artists will be at Penarth Pier Pavilion each afternoon from Wednesday  Feb  to Friday  March  to help build the Penarth Carnival.The drop-in sessions are for adults and families, and youngsters under  are asked to bring an adult.Nikki Fogaty, who helps run the mas camp for Butetown Carnival and will assist with the Penarth Carnival preparations, said: ldquoMas camp is sometimes a bit hectic, but can be great fun. You donrsquot need any experience, just be willing to join in. Come down with an idea for making a costume and find help. Therersquoll be experienced carnival makers here, andyou have got material then bring it, but you can just turn up.Artists from Penarth interested in being involved in the camp and helping with the carnival are invited to a meeting this Saturday  February  in the Beat Centre, West Close, Butetown from pm to pm. They can meet with Butetown artists to plan for the Penarth carnival.On Sunday  February  between pm-pm, interested residents can find out more about the festival at the Penarth Pier Pavilion. Members of the group developing the carnival will be meeting to share plans and welcome new ideas.Carnival organiser Richard Parry is also encouraging Penarth residents to book a day off work to enjoy the carnival on Monday, March .ldquoGive yourself a winter holiday break in your own town, he said Richard. ldquoTherersquos no queuing at airports, traffic jams or packing. Wersquore encouraging as many people in the town as possible to wriggle out of work and make a festival day.The festival will take place across Penarth from March  to March .A new website for the carnival has been launched.
